The High Priest states his position and *Invokes the Sages to Enter the Ritual Sequence*. Two members of the Daoist assembly proceed before the *Celestial Throne* to pour libations, while three *Reciters of Repentance* proclaim the liturgy. The Master of Rites invites the Ritual Patron to offer incense, perform three bows, and kneel. The High Priest re-enters the ritual sequence and *Pinches the First Incense*. The *Incense Attendant* first exits the ranks to offer incense to the East, South, West, and North. The Precentor next exits the ranks to offer incense at the *Jade Clarity Imperial Censer*. The High Priest offers incense at the *Cave Table*. Next, the *First Pinched Incense Talisman* is burned, and the visualization is performed. The *Knower of the Bell* intones the *First Pinched Incense Ode*, and the assembly responds. The Master of Rites invites the Ritual Patron to offer incense. The High Priest intones the *Chapter of the Demon Kings: "The Dao of Humanity Is Vast"*, and the assembly responds. The High Priest re-enters the ritual sequence and *Pinches the Second Incense*. The *Incense Attendant* offers incense to the Northeast, Southeast, Southwest, and Northwest. The Precentor offers incense at the *High Clarity Imperial Censer*. The High Priest offers incense at the *Cave Table*. The *Second Pinched Incense Talisman* is burned. The *Knower of the Bell* intones the *Second Pinched Incense Ode*, and the assembly responds. The Master of Rites invites the Ritual Patron to offer incense again. The High Priest intones *Lofty and Boundless*, and re-enters the ritual sequence to *Pinch the Third Incense*. Next, the *Incense Attendant* offers incense to the Above and Below. The Precentor offers incense at the *Grand Clarity Imperial Censer*. The High Priest offers incense at the *Cave Table*. The *Third Pinched Incense Talisman* is burned, and the visualization is performed. The *Knower of the Bell* intones the *Third Pinched Incense Ode*. The Master of Rites invites the Ritual Patron to offer incense three times. The High Priest intones *Above the Three Realms*. The High Priest enters the ritual sequence to *Harmonize with the Dao and Merge with the True*. The *Knower of the Bell* intones the *Celestial Worthy of the Numinous Treasure of the East*, and the assembly responds. Next, the Master of Rites invites the Ritual Patron to proceed before the *Celestial Worthy of the East*, offer incense, perform one bow, and kneel. The *Incense Attendant* and *Knower of the Bell* lead the High Priest to the East to offer incense, bow, and kneel. Next, the *Knower of the Bell* intones the *General Chant of the East*, and the *Reciters of Repentance* kneel to recite the *Eastern Repentance*, invoking the various spirit officials to *Harmonize with the Dao and Merge with the True*. The four directions begin with the East, followed by the four corners beginning with the Northeast, then the Above and Below, all in proper order. The *Knower of the Bell* intones the *Three Clarities and Three Treasures Heavenly Worthy*. The High Priest proceeds to the left, standing before the *Ghostly Portal* facing West, while the Precentor proceeds to the right, standing before the *Celestial Gate* facing East. Each visualizes the nine-colored circular image, its light illuminating the ten directions, swallows saliva to command the demons, and recites the secret incantation. Next, the High Priest recites the secret incantation. The Precentor intones, and the assembly circumambulates in *Step of Emptiness*. This may conclude with the daily noon audience’s demon-commanding rite, if desired. The *Knower of the Bell* intones the *Nine Yang Songs* in unison. The *Hymn of Huaxia* is intoned, and the ranks return to formation. Alternatively, flowers may be scattered during the three daily audiences’ circumambulation.

In the first circuit, the *Bowing in Reverence to the Most High* is intoned, and the final phrase is chanted in unison with the *Voice of Goodness*. In the second circuit, the *Treading of Cloud Steps in Procession* is intoned, passing through the towering peaks as the *Celestial Capital’s Mountain* is chanted as one verse. In the third circuit, the *Bowing and Rising* is performed while visualizing the *Most High*. The remaining six verses are divided between the noon and evening audiences, completing ten verses in a single day. Next, the Precentor intones the *Title of the Scripture*, and the *Knower of the Bell* intones the *First Inaugural Ode*. The Precentor intones *With Devoted Heart, Bow in Reverence to the Most High, the Boundless Great Dao*, and the *Knower of the Bell* intones the *Second Inaugural Ode*. Next, the *With Devoted Heart, Bow in Reverence to the Thirty-Six Divisions of the Venerable Scriptures* is intoned, and the *Knower of the Bell* intones the *Third Inaugural Ode*.

Next, the Precentor intones *With Devoted Heart, Bow in Reverence to the Great Dharma Master of the Mysterious Center*, and the *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Jade Talisman, the Heavenly Worthy Who Absolves Transgressions*.

The High Priest kneels and petitions, invoking the Jade Tablets of the Heavenly Official, the Earthly Official, and the Water Official, while the Reciter announces the tablets. The High Priest recites the incantations for each tablet, summons the generals, and the Reciter reads the memorials. The *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Dispatching Talisman Incantation, the Golden Radiance of Merit and Virtue*. The *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Heavenly Worthy of Great Unity, Savior from Suffering*.

In unison, the High Priest kneels and petitions, requesting to bow to the memorial of the Heavenly Worthy of Great Unity. The Announcer proclaims the memorial. The *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Hymn of Burning the Memorial*. The Reciter reads the memorials.

Next, the Precentor intones the recitation of the Dharma ranks once more. The High Priest enters the ritual section to express gratitude. The *Knower of the Bell* and the *Knower of the Bell Chime* strike the metal and jade instruments in alternation. The Precentor intones the *Twelve Vows*. Next, the *Visualization of the Spirit While Burning Incense* is intoned, the High Priest returns to the incense burner, and the *Hymn of Exiting the Hall* is chanted.

Next, the Attendant at the Incense Burner leads the assembly in a circuit, proceeding to exit the altar. The High Priest collects the memorial tablets and descends from the altar. Upon entering the altar, the High Priest leads; upon exiting, the Attendant at the Incense Burner leads, proceeding in order to the Master’s tent. The High Priest offers incense and kneels in gratitude. The Master of Ceremonies invites the Director of the Retreat to offer incense and perform three bows. The *Knower of the Bell* intones *Thus Far*, and the Announcer performs the *Dedication*. The Precentor intones the *Supervision of the Retreat and Correction of Transgressions*, and the Supervisor of the Retreat approaches the Master’s tent to offer incense and make a report.

The Banner Attendant leads the banners back to the tents in formation, and the Daoist assembly chants scriptures and performs the dedication. The Attendant at the Incense Burner leads the assembly to the Master’s hall, where the High Priest and the Director of the Retreat offer incense. Next, the *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Hymn of Taking Refuge in the Supreme Dao*. Next, the *Morning Petitions Concluded* is intoned. The officials return to their positions.

**Noon Audience of the First Day**
The order of the audience follows the same pattern as the morning audience. The High Priest recites the ritual section, proceeding to the first pinch of incense. The Incense Attendant offers incense, beginning from the South, then the West, the North, and the East. For the second pinch of incense, from the Southeast, Southwest, Northwest, and Northeast. For the third pinch of incense, from the Upper Realm and the Lower Realm. The High Priest recites the ritual section, proceeding to *Uniting with the Dao in Perfection*. The *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Heavenly Worthy, Supreme Minister of the Eastern Flowery Realm*. Next, the *Eastern Marchmount* is intoned in unison. The Reciter kneels and recites the *Repentance to the Eastern Marchmount*, then intones *The Heavenly Worthy Who Refines in the Southern Palace*.

Next, the *Southern Marchmount* is intoned in unison, and the Reciter kneels and proclaims the *Repentance to the Southern Marchmount*. The *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Heavenly Worthy, Protector of Virtue in the Western Numinous Realm*. Next, the *Western Marchmount* is intoned in unison, and the Reciter kneels and recites the *Repentance to the Western Marchmount*. Next, the *Heavenly Worthy, Supreme Inspector of the Northern Origin* is intoned, followed by the *Northern Marchmount* in unison, and the Reciter kneels and proclaims the *Repentance to the Northern Marchmount*. The *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Heavenly Worthy, August Emperor of the Central Yellow*, followed by the *Central Marchmount* in unison, and the Reciter kneels and proclaims the *Repentance to the Central Marchmount*. The *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Heavenly Worthy Who Pacifies and Stabilizes the Five Numinous Powers*, and the assembly returns to their positions. The Precentor intones the *Ritual for Subduing Demons*.

Next, the *Three Clarities and Three Treasures, Heavenly Worthies* is intoned, followed by the *Ten Hymns of Pacing the Void in the Jade Capital*. For a three-day, nine-audience retreat, when the *Knower of the Bell* intones the *Three Clarities and Three Treasures, Heavenly Worthies*, the assembly exits in order, circling the altar evenly and coming to a halt. Next, the Precentor intones the *Pacing the Void in Circuit*. Next, the *Knower of the Bell* intones *Bow in Reverence to the Most High*, and at the final verse, the assembly chants in unison the *Auspicious Sound* and each performs one bow. Next, the *Pacing the Void While Treading the Cloud Steps* is intoned, and the altar assembly rises to tread the *ding* steps of the *Gang* pattern, proceeding slowly. At the final verse of each hymn, the assembly chants in unison the *Auspicious Sound* and performs one bow.

For a single-day, three-audience retreat, at the noon audience, the *Controlling the Reins to Visit the Ten Directions*, *The Great Dao’s Master in Mysterious Quiescence*, and *The Garden of Rounded Scenery in the Forest of Soaring* are intoned as three hymns. Upon returning to their positions, the *Hua Xia* is used, and they come to a halt only after standing still. The rest follows the established pattern. After the *Three Inaugural Odes and Three Bows*, the High Priest petitions the *White Memorials and Talismanic Commands for the Nine Dark Realms* and the *Jade Tablets and Talismanic Commands for the Nine Dark Realms*. The High Priest bows to the memorial of the *Heavenly Worthy Who Embraces Transgressions in the Nine Dark Realms*. All follows the pattern of the morning audience.

**Evening Audience of the First Day**
The High Priest recites the ritual section, proceeding to the first pinch of incense. The Incense Attendant offers incense, beginning from the North, then the East, the South, and the West. For the second pinch of incense, from the Northwest, Northeast, Southeast, and Southwest. For the third pinch of incense, from the Upper Realm and the Lower Realm. Next, the *Repentance to the Five Stars* is performed. The *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Heavenly Worthy of True Light Illuminating the Caverns*. Next, the *Palace of the Sun* is intoned in unison, and the Reciter proclaims the *Repentance to the Palace of the Sun*. Next, the *Heavenly Worthy of Radiant Wisdom Illuminating* is intoned, followed by the *Palace of the Moon* in unison, and the Reciter proclaims the *Repentance to the Palace of the Moon*. Next, the *Heavenly Worthy of Flowing Radiance Shining* is intoned, followed by the *Palace of the Stars* in unison, and the Reciter proclaims the *Repentance to the Stars*. Next, the *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Heavenly Worthy of the Cavernous Samadhi*, followed by the *Palace of the Water Bureau* in unison, and the Reciter proclaims the *Repentance to the Palace of the Water Bureau*. Next, the *Heavenly Worthy of the Perfected Scripture Treasure* is intoned, followed by the *Palace of the Scripture Treasure* in unison, and the Reciter proclaims the *Repentance to the Scripture Treasure*. The *Knower of the Bell* intones *The Heavenly Worthy of the Supreme Jade Capital*, and the assembly returns to their positions. The Precentor intones the *Ritual for Dispelling Demons*, and the *Knower of the Bell* intones the *Three Clarities and Three Treasures, Heavenly Worthies*. Next, the *Nine Hymns of the Yin Songs* are intoned.

For a three-day, nine-audience retreat, at each morning audience, the *Nine Yang Hymns* are intoned, and at each evening audience, the *Nine Yin Hymns* are intoned. At each noon audience, the *Ten Great Pacing the Void* hymns are intoned. The beginning and ending procedures for the morning and evening audiences are the same as the *Ten Great Pacing the Void*. For a single-day, three-audience retreat, at the evening audience, the *Palace of the Heavenly Perfected Emperor* is intoned: *Adorning My Nine-Dragon Chariot, Perfect and Unattached in Truth*, completing ten hymns across the morning, noon, and evening audiences.

The High Priest petitions the *Golden Tablets of the Divine Empyrean* and the *Jade Tablets of the Divine Empyrean*, and bows to the memorial of the *Heavenly Worthy Who Vastly Delivers the Submerged*. The rest follows the established pattern.

**Morning Audience of the Second Day**
The Incense Attendant burns incense, and the Reciter recites the repentances for the directions, following the same pattern as the morning audience of the first day. The High Priest petitions the *Talismanic Commands of the Jade Tablets of the Three Heavenly Lords of the Upper Origin* and requests to bow to the memorial of the *Heavenly Worthy Who Delivers Lives in the Vermilion Mound*.

**Noon Audience of the Second Day**
All follows the same pattern as the noon audience of the first day. The High Priest petitions the *Golden Writs and Vermilion Scripts of the Precious Proclamations of the Nine Heavens of the Middle Origin* and requests to bow to the memorial of the *Heavenly Worthy of the Great Bridge of the Dharma*.

**Evening Audience of the Second Day**
All follows the same pattern as the evening audience of the first day. The High Priest petitions the *True Talismans of the Perfected Who Ascend to Transcendence, Liberating from the Cycles of Birth and Death* and requests to bow to the memorial of the *Heavenly Worthy, Sacred King of the Turning Wheel*.

**Morning Audience of the Third Day**
All follows the same pattern as before. The High Priest petitions the *Precious Proclamations of the Great Yang for Refining Form* and requests to bow to the memorial of the *Heavenly Worthy of the Cinnabar Realm of Fire Refinement*.

**Noon Audience of the Third Day**
All follows the same pattern as before. The High Priest petitions the *Jade Scripts of Thunder Patterns* and the *Longevity Memorial Texts*, and requests to bow to the memorial of the *Heavenly Worthy of the Golden Portal’s Transformation Body* and the *Memorial of Refinement through Water and Fire*.

**Evening Audience of the Third Day**
All follows the same pattern as before. After the *Three Invocations and Three Bows*, the High Priest petitions the *Precious Proclamations of the Great Yin for Refining Form* and the *True Talismans for Erasing Death and Ascending to Life*.

The rituals of the nine audiences follow the same pattern throughout, except for the repentance talismans and memorials. From the first to the third day, after each evening audience, the scripture attendants perform the *Lamp Rite for Gathering and Offering*.

After the morning audience of the third day, the Precentor and the assembly proceed to the *Celestial Offering Hall* to present offerings to the *Three Treasures and the Nine Heavens*, and conduct the ritual of offering to the *Sages of the Myriad Heavens* as prescribed.

After the eighth audience, the High Priest and the assembly, in accordance with the rites, present the *Texts of Thanksgiving for Blessings Received*. Following the subsequent evening audience—or after each morning audience of the three days—the imperial meal is offered. The detailed procedures are recorded separately.

**Conclusion of the Audience and Distribution of Alms**

In the *Hall of Assembled Masters*, the High Priest offers incense. The Ritual Director invites the *Fast-Officer* to offer incense and perform three bows. The *Bell-Master* intones the invocation to the *Jade Clarity Heavenly Worthy of Dispelling Filth*, and the Precentor recites the *Dispelling Filth Mantra*. The *Bell-Master* then intones the invocation to the *Golden Perfected Heavenly Worthy of Expounding the Teachings*. The assembly responds in unison three times. The incense attendants lead the ranks out of the altar space, circumambulating while offering incense, and proceed to the *Master’s Tent*. The High Priest makes a formal announcement, and the *Bell-Master* intones the chant. The incense attendants, led by *Song Huaxia*, guide the ranks to offer incense upon the altar. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Opening Hall Hymn*, and the Precentor leads the assembly in paying homage to the masters. The High Priest recites the *Guardian Spirit Mantra*. The Precentor strikes the *Dharma Drum*, and the High Priest kindles the incense burner. The drum is struck again. The officials then exit, and their ritual positions are announced. The High Priest enters the ritual protocol to invoke the presence of the sages. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Invocation of the Ten Directions’ Heavenly Worthies*. The *Bell-Master* then leads the assembly in bowing to the feet of the Worthies, each making sincere repentance. The Precentor guides the assembly in the *Ten Directions’ Seated Repentance*, and the *Bell-Master* intones the *Three Invocations and Three Bows*. The *Bell-Master* intones the invocation to the *Azure Radiance First Elder Heavenly Worthy*. The High Priest proceeds to the east, and the Ritual Director guides the *Fast-Officer* to the east to perform two bows, holding the incense burner and kneeling. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Eastern True Writ*, and the assembly pays homage to the master in gratitude. The High Priest recites the prayer of gratitude for the *True Writ*. The same procedure is followed in the south, west, north, and center. The High Priest then proceeds to the central incense burner, recites the prayer and mantra for the *True Writ*, and burns it. The assembly chants the *Golden Dragon* in response, and the *Four Tones of Pacification* are intoned as all return to their ranks. The Precentor announces the ritual positions again, and the High Priest re-enters the ritual protocol to recite the *Repentance and Liberation of the Altar*. The *Announcer* reads the memorial, and the *Bell-Master* intones the *Burning Memorial Hymn*. The High Priest performs the *Submission Rite* as prescribed, and the assembly responds in unison to the *Green Memorial* as directed. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Cloud Stairway Step Chant*. The High Priest re-enters the ritual protocol to make an announcement. The Ritual Director invites the *Fast-Officer* to offer incense and perform three bows. The *Bell-Master* intones the invocation to the *Heavenly Worthy of Repaying Virtue*. The High Priest recites the prayer four times, inviting the assembly to bow and present the *Memorial of Merit*. The *Announcer* reads the memorial aloud. The High Priest purifies the memorial with incense and then submits it. The *Announcer* reads the memorial’s conclusion, and the memorial is burned. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Burning Memorial Hymn*, and the assembly responds with the *Memorial Text* as directed. The *Bell-Master* intones the invocation to the *Three Clarities and Three Treasures Heavenly Worthies*. The High Priest recites the prayer to invoke the *Three Memorial Tablets*. The *Announcer* reads the *Mountain Tablet*. The High Priest recites the *Tablet Mantra*, then reads the *Water Tablet* and recites its mantra, followed by the *Earth Tablet* and its mantra. The assembly then pays homage to the *Three Treasures*. The High Priest declares:

*"Time flows swiftly, the sun’s shadow shifts unseen.
The Dao accords with the Primordial,
Its grace blankets the great earth.
The imperial realm endures,
The sage’s longevity spans the heavens."*

The assembly responds with bows of reverence, taking leave of the *Dao-Treasures of the Ten Directions*. The jade chimes fall silent, the sacred talismanic smoke dissipates. The masters return to the *Great Clarity*, illuminating the long night. The *Three Paths* cease their opposition, the *Six Realms* halt their turning wheels. The assembly responds with bows of reverence, taking leave of the *Scripture-Treasures of the Ten Directions*. May all beings refrain from evil, practice all virtues, avoid karmic entanglements, and abide in prosperous times. May all sentient beings realize the *Unconditioned*. The assembly responds with bows of reverence, taking leave of the *Master-Treasures of the Ten Directions*. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Returning Carriage Hymn*, and the High Priest descends to post the *Eight Gates’ Placards*. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Descending Altar Hymn*, followed by the *Twelve Vows*. The Precentor then leads the *Spirit-Preserving Incense Offering*, and the High Priest rekindles the incense burner. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Exiting Hall Hymn* and the *Extinguishing Lamps Hymn*, and the altar lamps are extinguished in order. The incense attendants lead the ranks down from the altar to stand in sequence before the *Six Tents*. The High Priest and the *Fast-Officer* offer incense. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Respectful Devotion of Each Participant*. The High Priest delivers the prayer of gratitude. The *Announcer* reads the *Memorial of Mystic Gratitude*. The *Six Tents* join the High Priest in offering a universal prayer of gratitude. The Precentor leads the *Universal Penance of the Fast-Supervisor*, and the *Fast-Supervisor* kneels to report the universal penance. The Precentor instructs the officials to kneel in unison and return the precepts as prescribed. The High Priest delivers the admonition for returning the precepts. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Returning Precepts Hymn*, and the Precentor leads the officials in submitting their ranks. The *Announcer* collects the *Rank Tablets*. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Hymn for Sending Off the Six Tents*, followed by the *Cloud Chariot Hymn* and the *Sending Off the Masters Hymn*. The *Bell-Master* intones the invocation to the *Heavenly Worthy of Turning the Light and Returning the Carriage*, escorting the true masters back to the *Hall of Assembled Masters*. The *Fast-Officer* offers incense and performs the bows. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Fourfold Concluding Vows*. The officials offer their thanks in order.

---

**Transmission of Precepts and Bestowal of Registers**
The Daoist assembly gathers at the *Hall of Proper Attainment*. A master in ritual vestments delivers the invocation to invite the *Spirit Banner*. The *Announcer* chants the verse, and the altar attendant holds the banner aloft. The *Bell-Master* intones the invocation to the *Heavenly Worthy of Great Compassion and Reception*, welcoming and inviting the *Banners of Attachment and Deliverance*. The general altar is set at the western edge, with the *Soul Banner* positioned. The High Priest’s seat is arranged at the eastern edge. The High Priest delivers the ritual address, indicating the seat. He then ascends the seat, offers incense, expounds the Dao, and strikes the ritual ruler to enter the protocol. The *Bell-Master* intones the invocation to the *Dao, Scriptures, and Masters Heavenly Worthies*. The assembly responds in unison as the High Priest rises, holding the incense burner to invite the *Three Treasures and Five Masters* to witness the transmission of precepts. The High Priest re-enters the ritual protocol. The *Bell-Master* intones the *Respectful Devotion of Each Participant*, followed by the *Hymn of Bowing in Refuge to the Dao, Scriptures, and Masters*. The High Priest re-enters the protocol, and the *Bell-Master* intones the *Wisdom Hymn*, followed by the invocation to the *Heavenly Worthy of Compassionate Precept-Teaching*. The High Priest strikes the *Dharma Ruler* and expounds the *Nine Wondrous Precepts of the Perfected*, then intones the *Receiving Precepts Hymn*. The various grades of *Talismans and Registers* are then conferred. The *Announcer* reads the *Precept Certificate* and the *Merit Certificate*. The High Priest recites the general *Talisman Mantra*. The High Priest delivers the ritual address and descends from the seat.

**Severing the Corpse and Delivering the Households through Refinement**
The *Bell-Master* intones the invocation to the *Heavenly Worthy of Flying Deliverance through the Five Households*. The *Fast-Officer* holds the *Proper Attachment-Deliverance Bridge*. The High Priest performs the ritual with sword and sprinkled water. The *Announcer* reads the *Memorial for the Three Corpses’ Talisman*. The High Priest invokes the spirits of the *Three Corpses*. The *Announcer* recites the *Prayer for the Three Corpses’ Talisman*. The *Announcer* recites the *Verse for Delivering the Households*, leading the banner through the *Five Gates of Suffering*. At each gate, the ritual verse is recited, delivering the banner to the *Refinement Altar*. Silver coins are then arranged in the shape of the *Dipper* on the ground—a total of forty-nine coins, with seven coins in each of the seven piles. The High Priest, from *Wei* to *Kui*, performs the ritual with the *Jade Seal*. The assembly recites the *Returning Spirit Mantra*, and the *Seven Qi* coalesce into perfection.

The High Priest next announces the *Talisman for Resolving Grievances*, and the assembly proceeds together to the *Refinement Altar*. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to commence the ritual. One set of ritual robes is prepared for the *Three Offerings of Refinement*. The High Priest requests and bows to the *Memorial for the Nine Heavens’ Refinement*, and the *Announcer* reads the *Memorial for the Refinement*. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to recite the *Hymn for Burning the Memorial*, then reads the *Petition for the Refinement* before burning it. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Nine Radiance Refinement Heavenly Worthy*, while the *Purification Attendant* holds the basin to sprinkle purification water. The assembly circumambulates the altar, reciting the *Purification Mantra*.

The High Priest ascends the seat, offers incense, and invokes the deities to enter the ritual. He requests and bows to the *Memorial for Water and Fire*, and the *Recitation Attendant* reads the memorial. The High Priest prostrates with the memorial, the *Announcer* reads the *Official Document*, and the *Announcer* strikes the chime to recite the *Hymn for Burning the Memorial*. Next, the *Universal Radiance of Sun and Moon Heavenly Worthy* is invoked.

The High Priest holds the water basin, steps the *Dipper Pace*, and harmonizes the *qi*, then casts the talisman into the water pool. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to recite *With Sincere Heart, We Take Refuge and Bow in Faith*, addressing the *Great Yin Sovereign of the Moon Palace*. Next, the *Incantation for Gazing Across the Eight Directions* is recited, followed by *Juewu Ziyu*, summoning the *Great General of the Water Lord*. The *Document for the Water Lord General* is cast. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Universal Radiance of Sun and Moon Heavenly Worthy*. The High Priest holds the censer, steps the *Dipper Pace*, and harmonizes the *qi*, then casts the talisman into the fire pool. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to recite *With Sincere Heart, We Take Refuge and Bow in Faith*, addressing the *Great Yang Emperor of the Sun Palace*. Next, the *Incantation for Gazing East to Fusang Palace* is recited, followed by *Nanyan Dongfu*, summoning the *Great General of the Fire Lord*. The *Document for the Fire Lord General* is cast.

The *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Nine Radiance Refinement Heavenly Worthy*, then recites the *Hymn for Spreading the Seat*. The priest supplicates: *"I humbly invoke the Nine Radiance Azure Gold Western Han Lady, the Primordial Sovereign Golden Mother of the Great Realized, to descend with true qi and infuse the Flowery Pond."* The *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Wondrous Fruit and Pure Moon Heavenly Worthy*. The *Water Talisman* is conferred, and the *Yellow Crystal Illumination Incantation* is recited, followed by the *Incantations for Descending Water Talismans* in sequence.

The priest supplicates: *"I humbly invoke the Primordial Yang Compassionate Father, Fusang Great Emperor, Lord of the Wooden Duke, to descend with true qi and illuminate the divine court."* Next, the *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Compassionate Radiance of the Vermilion Sun Heavenly Worthy*. The *Fire Talisman* is cast, and the *Red Furnace Cinnabar Radiance Incantation* is recited, followed by the *Incantations for Descending Fire Talismans* in sequence. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Heavenly Worthy Who Delivers the Infinite*.

The High Priest enters the ritual. *"I have heard that the Infinite Deliverer, the Great Sage of Longevity..."* Next, the *Ten Directions’ Flying Heavenly Spirit Kings* are summoned to oversee the deliverance and protection, and the *Four Protections* are recited. The *Four Guardians* are united, the *Official Document* is read, the *Day-Official Merit Clerk* is summoned, and the generals are called to guide the souls to the *Water Refinement*.

The *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Heavenly Worthy of Unfettered Spiritual Power*, and the banner is moved to the edge of the water pool. The High Priest enters the ritual, and the *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Yellow Flower Purifying Form Heavenly Worthy*. The *Water Lord General* is summoned to perform the *Water Refinement*, and the *Water Refinement Talismans* are cast in sequence, followed by the *Nine Water Rebirth Talismans*. The *Union* is performed. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to recite the *Verse of the Eastern Well and Yellow Flower Pool*. Next, the incantations are recited in order.

The banner is then moved to stand by the fire pool. The High Priest enters the ritual, and the *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Heavenly Worthy of Jade Eyes Refining Essence*. The *Fire Lord General* is summoned to perform the *Fire Refinement*, and the *Fire Refinement Talismans* are cast in sequence, followed by the *Nine Fire Rebirth Talismans*. The *Union* is observed. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to recite the *Verse of the Southern Supreme Vermilion Mansion*. Next, the incantations are recited in order. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Heavenly Worthy Who Gathers the Realized and Restores the Spirit*.

The High Priest re-enters the ritual, rises, holds the banner, and performs the *Intertwined Refinement Method*, reciting the *Heaven One Generates Water Incantation* three times. The banner is then burned in the fire. As the form burns in the furnace, the true *qi* is reborn. The *Transcendent Banner* is exchanged and erected beside the *Qi-Gathering Furnace*, signifying rebirth and renewal.

The High Priest enters the ritual and burns the *Eighteen Great Cavern Talismans*, harmonizing the *qi* with each talisman. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Heavenly Worthy of Returning Form and Transformation*. The High Priest re-enters the ritual, then invokes the *Heavenly Worthy of the Golden Portal’s Transformation*. Next, the *Three Clarities and Three Treasures Heavenly Worthies* are invoked. The *Nine Chapters’ Talismans*—three sets of nine—are presented, with the assembly reciting one *Heavenly Chapter* for every three talismans. The *Announcer* strikes the chime to invoke the *Heavenly Worthy of the Nine Qi Generating the Spirit*. The *Five Spirits’ Union Talisman* and its incantation are recited, followed by the *Jade Infant’s Spirit Transformation Talisman* and its incantation. The *Transcendent Transformation into Human Talisman* and its incantation are recited.

The *Yellow Register of Dao Transmission* is conferred, and the *Great Ascension Mantra* is recited. The High Priest performs the *Ascension and Deliverance Method*, the *Wisdom Hymn*, and sends off the souls. He descends from the seat, takes leave of the *Three Treasures*, sends off the deities, and summons the *Five Directions’ Divine Lads* to board the chariot. The *Verse of Crossing the Bridge* is recited, the *Three Chapters of the Demon Kings* are chanted, and the offerings are burned. The *Merit* is recited, and gratitude is expressed.

The ritual concludes as the assembly gathers in the master’s hall.

The Precentor intones the *Jade Clarity Venerable of Purging Defilements*. Next, the Cantor recites the *Purging Defilements Mantra*. The Precentor then intones *Each Attendant Reverently Submits*. Following this, the *Master of the Retreat* leads the *Hua Xia* procession, guiding the assembly in circumambulation while offering incense. The *Incense-Burning Hymn* is intoned, and the Cantor leads the assembly in paying homage to the master. The High Priest recites the *Guardian Spirit Mantra*. The ritual drum is sounded, the incense burner is kindled, and the drum is struck again to summon the officiants. The Cantor leads the assembly in declaring their ritual ranks, and the High Priest invokes the deities, proceeding to the *Invitation Rite*.

Two Daoist officiants divide into left and right ranks, ascending in alternating order to request the presence of the deities along the corridor. The High Priest offers the prayer: *"All Perfected Ones of the Ten Directions, the Hosts of the Three Realms, array your immortal ranks to reverently welcome the Imperial Chariot."* The *Yellow Path Mantra* is recited. Next, the assembly kneels and prostrates to petition the *Four Masters and Four Emperors of the Divine Empyrean*.

The Precentor intones the *Great Clarity Melody* to invite the *Great Clarity*. The Precentor intones the *High Clarity Melody* to invite the *High Clarity*. The Precentor intones the *Jade Clarity Melody* to invite the *Jade Clarity*. The *Cloud Chariot Hymn* is recited, and the High Priest offers the prayer: *"The Three Clarities descend in their chariots, the Four Emperors attend in state. We humbly invite the hosts of the Three Realms to array their ranks in homage. The rites of homage now complete, each spreads the feast of offering. With utmost sincerity, we present the first incense."* The Precentor intones the *Scattering Flowers*, and the assembly circumambulates to the incense burner before the grotto altar. The High Priest and the Retreat Master offer incense, while the Direct Attendant presents tea and pours wine. The Precentor intones the *Long Chant of Ritual Affairs* before the burner.

The Cantor leads the assembly in declaring their ritual ranks once more, and the High Priest proceeds with the rite, reciting the *Petition and Repentance Texts*. The High Priest dispatches the officiants. Next, the *Fumigation Mantra* is recited, followed by the *Step Pace and Prostration Petition*. The Precentor intones the *Fumigation Hymn*, and the High Priest proceeds with the rite for the *Second Offering*. The *Second Offering Ritual* is performed, and the High Priest proceeds with the rite. For the *Third Offering*, the Announcer reads the *Memorial and Petition Documents*. The Precentor intones the *Third Offering Ritual*, and the High Priest, with renewed sincerity, presents the final petition before proceeding to the *Rite of Sending Off the Deities*.

Next, the Precentor intones the *Return Chariot Hymn*, followed by the *Yellow Path Mantra*. The Cantor leads the *Meditation and Incense Offering*, and the High Priest rekindles the incense burner. The Precentor intones the *Venerable of Perfect Treasure’s Completion*, guiding the assembly to the burning site. The Precentor intones the *Hymn of Sagely Virtue*, and the assembly returns to their original positions. The Announcer performs the *Merit Transfer*. The officiants express their gratitude.

**Release of Living Beings Rite**
The assembly gathers before the altar, and the Precentor intones the *Step Pace Chant*. The Announcer invokes the deities and proceeds with the rite. Next, the *Venerable of Life-Preserving Destiny* is intoned, and the Announcer recites the *Release of Living Beings Mantra*. The *Petition Document* is read, followed by the intoning of the *Venerable of Carefree Joy*. The Announcer recites the mantra again. The *Petition Document* is read, followed by the intoning of the *Venerable of Boundless Blessing*, and the Announcer recites the mantra once more. The *Petition Document* is read, and an officiant in ritual vestments delivers the *Release of Living Beings Invocation* before performing the release. The assembly recites scriptures, and the Precentor intones the *Return Chant*. The Announcer performs the *Merit Transfer*, the *Fourfold Aspirations* are made, and the officiants disperse.

The Gate of Divine Banners and Precious Canopies

When one allies with Heaven and petitions Earth, summons the perfected and invokes the numinous, radiates luminous command over demons, and deploys the Ninefold Brilliance and Tenfold Severance, all serve to establish images according to ritual, embodying forms in full likeness—towering in the void, illuminating the Dharma-realm, piercing the dark and obscure, and transforming and delivering devas and humans.

Even to the cutting of clouds and unfurling of brocade, the spreading of brocade-like radiance and rosy dawn, the spurring of light to ride the void, and the congealing of spirit to merge with qi—thus do the hosts of heavens chant from afar, the myriad sages descend to the throne, the long night bursts into light, and the Nine Dark Realms cease their trials. The merit is vast indeed.

Therefore, the great Dharma of the Divine Treasure—its banners, streamers, staffs, and canopies—possesses its complete rituals. One must especially move the ancestral qi to merge with the divine radiance, exhaust the subtlest essence to achieve the boundless, adapt to conditions and manifest transformations, and respond to thoughts with spiritual resonance. It serves as the ford shared by life and death and the standard for revealing the hidden.

When it forms the void into the Brahmā-realm, when cloud-script fills the Great Void, when forms transform across the ten directions and spirits transcend the eight limits—universally aiding the sentient, broadly delivering the submerged—it is truly the ultimate aim of the Dao and Dharma, the ritual norm of purification and cultivation.

Vast and majestic above, how could it be neglected?
[Preserve and employ.]

When erecting banners and canopies, one must concentrate the spirit and visualize this direction as a vast sea palace, its silver waves suffusing the heavens, utterly free from obscurity or hindrance. Transform the erected banner into a crimson tally of rainbow streamers, a mushroom-canopied treasure-pavilion. Sun, moon, and starlight gleam resplendently upon it; auspicious winds stir and dance as its shadow ripples across golden lotuses. Brahmā-qi suffuses the expanse, its majesty towering like a celestial terrace.

Next, visualize one’s own primordial palace-qi merging within and without, mysteriously uniting with the treasures of heaven. Mounting the radiance of a hundred jewels, it illuminates the ten directions, universally aiding all existence. Heavenly perfected beings, the Great Sages of the Thirty-Two Heavens, and the exalted venerables of the upper realms all come to celebrate the assembly. This is the true efficacy of exalting virtue, establishing merit, summoning the perfected, and invoking the numinous.

At the appointed time, the ritual will proceed in due order: reciting the profound liturgies, presenting memorials and petitions, issuing talismanic decrees, redeeming the sinful and the lost, releasing those in dark confinement, kindling lamps to perpetuate light, invoking radiance to dispel obscurity, universally bestowing *hú* offerings, summoning the departed souls, bathing and reclothing them, guiding them to attend the assembly of perfected beings and receive the Dharma, transmitting talismans and conferring precepts, refining and delivering them to rebirth. Upon completion, the merits will be declared in a memorial, *Dragon Tablets* will be cast into the waters, and a pure *jiao* offering will be reverently prepared to give thanks for the boundless grace. All accumulated virtues will be dedicated to the ascension of the departed, humbly beseeching the sagely blessings to universally succor both the living and the dead. The sincerity of the fast is thus openly proclaimed in this memorial.

This principle must be thoroughly examined.

**Summoning, Employment, and Dispatching Gate**
Now, as for summoning, employment, and dispatching—unless one first illuminates the wondrous subtleties of the precelestial Great Dao and its numinous transformations, how could one partake in this?
For what reason?
From Non-Ultimate to Supreme Ultimate is the void transforming into spirit. The Supreme Ultimate’s movement as yang and stillness as yin is spirit transforming into qi. From this qi, pervading between Heaven and Earth, there arise humans and things. Humans, as the most numinous of things, within their nature and destiny possess all principles. Thus they parallel Heaven and Earth, assist in transformation and nurturance. When mind knows and intent arises, spirit moves and Heaven follows. Moreover, ghosts and spirits are the innate capacities of the two qi, the functioning of creation. Those who ride the sun and moon, embrace the cosmos, mount cloud-qi, and drive flying dragons—are they not the transformations of the numinous? Yet amid the ten thousand transformations, there must also be a governing spirit. Tracing its origin, this governing spirit is nowhere yet everywhere, neither form nor void. Its function is boundless, its substance traceless, yet it can command the ten thousand qi and unite the hundred spirits. Thus there are those who, without speaking, respond with goodness, and without being summoned, come of themselves. Therefore, the Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure, in commanding the ten thousand offices, derive from this above. Yet one fears that as affairs daily entangle and human desires deepen, one may fail to reach the root and thus not penetrate the mysterious. Therefore, one must employ visualization, concentration, and thought, moving spirit to meet the Dao, aligning qi with qi, spirit with spirit, intermingling with the numinous. By refining sincerity and reverence, one may bridge the high and the low without gap, the distant and near without difference. Reaching through earnestness and communicating sincerity, one aids the living and delivers the dead. In a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, responding to thought and penetrating all—this is none other than the wondrous flow of the primordial Great Dao. Summoning, employment, and dispatching are indeed the guiding principles of the Daoist arts—how could one not be cautious in this?

**The Gate of Lamp Division and Ritual Implement Regulation**

The *Scripture* states: "The revelation of the Three Luminaries is called the Root of Heaven." Thus, the primordial, original, and initial Three Qi are the root and origin of the myriad transformations, the great foundation of heaven and humanity. From this, the vast and formless Great Brahmā unfolds; the Three Qi radiate light, giving birth to heaven and earth, sun and moon, stars and constellations. Therefore, in the grand rites of the Numinous Treasure, at the inception of altar establishment, one models the principle of the primordial chaos’s first division. Thus, lamps are divided and torches arrayed to unfold the light of the Three Qi and generate the Three Luminaries. Bells are rung and jade chimes struck to harmonize yin and yang, giving rise to the myriad transformations—all in accord with the natural workings of heaven.

One must understand that formless qi is the Ancestral Qi, and colorless light is the Light of Wisdom. From one comes three, from three extends nine; through the ninefold nine transformations, the myriad lights are born. They illumine the ten thousand heavens, brighten the nine earths, and penetrate within and without, inheriting their brilliance. Only then does one respond to the soundless sound within the gold and jade, and enact the unchanging transformation beyond yin and yang. Taking the Dao as essence, all sentient beings and creeping creatures shall forever have a refuge. Such is the wondrous subtlety of the Dao’s profound and mysterious workings—how could there be any separation between the hidden and the manifest, the lofty and the deep?

**On the Casting of Bells and Chimes**

The method states: Cast bells from metal, and when struck, their sound first summons the yang spirits. Carve chimes from jade, and when sounded, their resonance first summons the yin spirits. These are the finest instruments for harmonizing yin and yang.

The master should:
- Strike the teeth on the left to sound the golden bell twenty-five times, summoning the martial hosts.
- Strike the teeth on the right to sound the jade chime thirty times, gathering the perfected spirits.
- Strike the teeth at the center to beat the ritual drum twenty-four times, making it heard by the Celestial Emperor.

Internally, these follow the numbers of heaven and earth’s yin and yang; externally, they unfold the nine harmonies and ten unions of sound. First, invoke the barrier-warding and altar-guarding generals, burn the talismans, proclaim the documents, strike the jade, and sound the metal—only then may the spirits be summoned to descend.

**The Rite of Commanding Water and Warding the Altar**

The Dao’s essence is utmost emptiness; without emptiness, it cannot respond to phenomena. Human nature is fundamentally good; without goodness, the Dao cannot be illuminated. The nature of water is likewise—only through goodness can it benefit all things. The Great Rites of Numinous Treasure include the *Rite of Commanding Water and Warding the Altar*, which draws the upright *qi* of the Three Luminaries, circulates the true essence of the Nine Phoenixes, summons and deploys the myriad spirits, exhales and inhales the Two *Qi*, treads the *Dipper’s* path, and establishes the altar’s sacred boundary. In small measure, it purifies and solemnizes the four quarters; in great measure, it clarifies and brightens heaven and earth. By adorning the inner and outer rites, it aligns the descent of spirits above and below. Thus, purity in fasting is foremost, and sincerity in clarity is fundamental. For the perverse can only encroach upon the upright—without upright *qi*, one cannot dispel what is false. Filth can only corrupt the true—without true *qi*, one cannot cleanse what is defiled. Thus, the *qi* of upright truth engenders the marvel of transformation and circulation.

Now, with inner and outer integrity, nature and Dao both luminous, all realms purified, and not a speck of dust adhering—is this not the efficacy of gathering emptiness and congealing spirit?

**Chapter on Visualization for Commanding the Altar**

For the *Rite of Commanding the Altar*, first place the *Water Sword* at the *Earth Gate*. Select a Daoist of dignified bearing to prepare the altar tablet and proceed to the *Earth Gate* where the *Sword* and water are stationed. The *qi* of heaven and earth is what first gives birth; all things emerge and enter through it. Thus, the southeast is the extreme of yang and the birth of yin—hence, the southeast is the *Earth Gate*. The northwest is the extreme of yin and the birth of yang—hence, the northwest is the *Heavenly Gate*. Therefore, in the practice of *Morning Audience with the Perfected*, one always departs from yin to approach yang.

First, close the eyes and visualize the Three Masters of the Scriptural Transmission facing west. Next, visualize the *Great General of Concealing the Body*, surnamed Tang, named Hong, styled Wenming, wearing a crimson yang-red headband and a *Tongtian* crown, clad in vermilion robes, girded with a jade sword bearing a dragon’s head, and holding a golden talisman in his left hand. Then visualize the *Great General of Hidden Shadow*, surnamed Ge, named Yong, styled Wendu, wearing a crimson yang-blue headband and a *Tongtian* crown, clad in vermilion robes, and wielding a jade halberd. Next, visualize the *Great General of Concealed Form*, surnamed Zhou, named Wu, styled Wengang, wearing a crimson yang-red headband and a *Tongtian* crown, clad in vermilion robes, and holding a *Yang Jade* staff.

Next, visualize the Perfected Officials in crimson robes riding the Nine Phoenixes. Then, step the *Dipper of Breaking Filth*, visualizing the Seven Stars of the Northern Dipper covering one’s head, the Dipper’s handle pointing forward without obstructing the ears or eyes. Next, assume the ritual position, announce the purpose of the fast, and conclude with the Three Bows. Retrieve the altar tablet, let the hands hang naturally, and clench the fists to summon the Four Numinous Beasts.

The Four Numinous Beasts are the Azure Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, and Dark Warrior. With the left hand, form the twelve mudras, visualizing the *qi* of the liver and heart transforming into their forms, emerging to stand at the left front. Then, with the right hand, form the *You* and *Zi* mudras, visualizing the *qi* of the lungs and kidneys transforming into their forms, emerging to stand at the right rear. Next, clasp the hands over the heart, stand in the *Ding*-character stance, and recite the *Summons of the Three Officials*. Then, step the *Three Officials’* *Ding* *Dipper* three times toward the *Sword* and water, and afterward, form the five-direction mudras to summon the Five Dragons.

Upon completion, take up the *Sword* and water, face the direction, and hold the incantation. Next, approach the altar and sprinkle the purificatory water. Upon finishing, proceed through the *Human Gate*, step the *Yu* step and *Dipper*, advance to the *Ghost Gate*, strike with the sword, and retreat. Then, bow three times, and press the middle finger of the middle hand. Visualize all the spirits transforming and the true *qi* returning to one’s body.

**Gate of the Night-Opening Morning Offering**
The Dao states: The transformations of heaven and earth, the Dao of the sages—these lie in non-action and spontaneity alone.
For non-action and spontaneity mean neither striving nor deliberation.
Within this neither-striving-nor-deliberation, profound as the ancestor of the myriad things, lies the great root of heaven and humanity.
Yet those who can embody sincerity and reverence, harmonize heaven and humanity, and unify them in the Dao—thus the teachings prescribe the Dao of morning cultivation.
Morning cultivation occurs thrice daily, establishing the altar to perform the Dao, offering rites of gratitude to the Primordial.
This embodies the principle of thrice-daily communion, daily proclaiming the Three Virtues.
Extending this to three days and nine mornings also follows the number of the Nine Yang.
Thus, the sincerity of nine prostrations and nine offerings is fulfilled.
Its purport declares: The divine transformation of the Precious Pearl, the Great One containing the true,
The Five *Qi* paying homage to the Primordial, the Three Flowers gathering at the crown—this is called the inner vision.

The inscribing of flying petitions and talismans, the performance of ritual protocols to expound the Dao, the transcription of prayers and presentation of memorials, the rites of repentance and gratitude—these are called the outer visions.

Thus, all outer visions are fundamentally rooted in the wonders of the inner vision. Without profound clarity regarding the Dao of inner and outer, who could fully grasp their essence and function?

Now, considering the essence of the Dao: it is so small that nothing lies within it, yet the myriad things share a single root. Extending to the function of the Dao: it is so vast that nothing lies beyond it, yet from this single root arise the myriad things.

Thus, one must further understand that which constitutes its essence: it abides in being yet leaves no trace. That which constitutes its function: it originates in non-being yet enables action.

From this perspective, one may attain vastness while exhausting subtlety, uniting inner and outer while embracing both essence and function. In all that is spoken, there is nothing that is not the wonder of non-action and spontaneity.

Therefore, in the moments of morning cultivation and reverent audience, how could one be negligent or allow interruption?

**Lingbao Natural Contemplation of Divine Rites and Formulas**

The *Suqi* (Evening Prelude) takes place on the day before the formal retreat. At an auspicious hour, the altar is established, mats are arranged, offices are filled, precepts are recited, the assembly is exhorted, and the Three Realms are notified—this is the evening of the announcement, not the day of the formal retreat when the Dao is practiced.

The master says: On the following morning, the Dao is practiced, and the announcement is made again. On the appointed day, the practice begins at the first dawn audience.

Thus, the *Suqi* notification and memorial are not part of the formal retreat’s Dao practice.

Those observing the retreat must, on the preceding day, bathe and reside in the retreat quarters. At the auspicious hour of the appointed day, the assembly is led in full dignity to escort the High Priest and Master before the master’s seat. The retreat officer is invited to burn incense and present the retreat petition to the High Priest.

Then, the High Priest, standing before the master, announces the intent of the retreat.

The retreat’s discipline is most solemn: all the celestial worthies and sagely beings descend to oversee it. Every matter must conform to the proper standards. Even the recitations, chants, and hymns of the *Dujang* must be paced appropriately—neither rushed nor delayed.

When the High Priest makes announcements, he stands facing east, holding the tablet, bowing slightly, modulating his voice, and regulating his *qi*. His words should be direct, plain, and unadorned, without excessive embellishment.

For all prayers and supplications, repentance must precede the request.

Whenever the High Priest ascends the altar to practice the Dao, he washes his hands and rinses his mouth with fragrant water—this is called *Danghui* (Dispelling Impurities). Afterward, he does the same—this is called *Bizhenqi* (Sealing the True *Qi*).

**Altar Rites and Ritual Forms**

To establish an altar and raise its curtains, to assign offices and divide duties, to honor virtue and repay merit, to reverently conclude and pursue what is distant—this is the noble intent of filial children, benevolent persons, righteous men, and chaste women. Thus, one models heaven and emulates earth, arrays the Dipper and encircles the stars, aligns the Eight Trigrams and Nine Palaces, encompasses the ten directions and three realms, and fully prepares the Jade Capital and Golden Towers herein.

As for the majesty of the Dao and its rites, the advance and retreat of ceremony and music, the movement of spirit in accord with the Way, treading upon radiance and soaring through mystery—ascending and descending with solemnity, responding without negligence—all emerges from the transformative operation of the Dharma-nature, each detail aligning with its yang virtue and yin merit. In ancient times of great peace, the principle of three altars sharing a single sacred space was no different from this.

To ascend this altar, one must first attune the heart to the profound mystery and spirit to the Sovereign of the Void. Then shall the Three Realms revere, the myriad spirits pay homage, and the boundless presence above—though unseen—draw near. A single misguided thought, and one is sundered by a thousand leagues.

Thus, the great rites of the Numinous Treasure have descended into the human realm since high antiquity. From the Qin and Han onward, perfected beings emerged. After the Jin and Song dynasties, the Way flourished. Lu Jianji pioneered its teachings, Zhang Qingdu followed in succession, and Du Guangcheng and others came after, with masters and disciples transmitting the lineage through generations, tracing its source and following its stream—its origins clear and continuous. If sincerity and reverence remain unbroken, then resonance and response arise naturally. This is the enduring principle observed through past and present, the shared blessing of heaven and humanity.

When the nine audiences conclude their affairs and report their accomplishments, the altar is dismantled, the seats dispersed, the radiant procession turns back, and all falls into profound silence—vast, mysterious, and utterly transcendent. Thus, all celestial and human beings receive blessings without exception. Boundless fortune extends its grace to the living and the dead, confirming these words as true.

**Central Altar**
Use eight long *zuan* and four gate placards, with two *zuan* framing each placard as a gate. Twenty short *zuan* and twenty mats. Use eighteen long *zuan* and ten gate placards, with two *zuan* framing each placard as a gate. Ten short *zuan*, ten mats. Ancient regulations for the inner altar permit entry only through the Heavenly Gate.

**Regulations for the Imperial Altar**
The right altar may be constructed of precious bricks, patterned stone, bamboo or wood (temporarily arranged), or rammed earth—whatever conforms to the prescribed standards to uphold the rites of imperial audience. It may stand exposed beneath the Three Luminaries to convey utmost sincerity, or be modeled after the *Celestial Treasure Terrace*, emulating the celestial realms. When establishing a fast and performing the Dao, first arrange the three sacred positions of the *Most High* at the center, as if attending the *Jade Capital Mountain*.

The three-tiered altar requires sixty-four *zuan*: thirty-four long ones, each twelve *chi* in length, and thirty short ones, each ten *chi* long. The heads of each *zuan* are fashioned into lotus shapes. Twenty-two gate placards are used: seven black, five yellow, three white, three azure, and four red, adorned with the five colors and distributed across the three tiers of the altar *zuan* according to the prescribed numbers. Carved wooden plaques bearing the forms of flying immortals and cloud *qi* are affixed, crafted with utmost precision.

Around the outer edge of the three-tiered altar, install railings and erect three rows of long and short *zuan*. Bind them with five hundred *chi* each of azure and crimson cords to purify and separate the sacred from the profane. According to ancient ritual, the central altar spans thirty-two *chi*, the inner altar twenty-four *chi*, and the outer altar lies beyond the central altar. Modern constructions should adapt to the available space. The length of the *zuan* may be fixed, but the short ones should be adjusted to the altar’s dimensions.

The Method of Pacifying Trust

The method of pacifying trust takes the dragon as foremost; any deficiency is examined by the Bureau of Yin Officials.

**Pacifying Silks**
Ten segments for the ten directions, each assigned one measure of trust.
East: nine segments of blue; South: three segments of crimson; West: seven segments of white; North: five segments of black; Above: thirty-two segments of azure; Below: thirty-two segments of yellow; the four corners: twelve segments each of yellow. The total for the ten directions is one hundred thirty-six.
The Son of Heaven uses bolts; nobles, zhang; commoners, chi.
The twisted silks: the Son of Heaven and nobles use purple; officials and commoners use the color corresponding to their natal *nayin*.
The inner measure of trust—bolt, zhang, or chi—is increased by one according to the year. These are displayed as silken pledges of extended life, placed at the center of the altar.
The ritual states: The five-colored twisted silks manifest the colors of the Five Phases, symbolizing the *qi* of the ten directions. They descend from the Ten Heavens, summon the Five Emperors, and communicate with the Perfected to fulfill trust, to petition for destiny, and to invoke numinous power—none may be omitted. Any deficiency is examined by the Bureau of Celestial Officials of the Mystic Capital.

**Ten Sets of Paper, Brush, Ink, and Inkstone for the Ten Directions**
The ritual states: When establishing a fast and performing the Dao, whether to deliver the myriad generations of ancestors and the recently departed, or to petition for blessings, beseech grace, dispel calamities, and repent transgressions, the Four Administrations, Five Emperors, Three Realms, and Ten Directions record merit, assess transgressions, and determine judgments. Paper, brush, ink, and inkstone serve as the registers of merit and the records of good deeds, substantiating trust before the ten directions—none may be omitted. If deficient, the Ten Heavens will not record merit, and the Nine Dark Hells and Three Officials will not remit punishment; any deficiency is examined by the Bureau of the Three Officials.

**Ten Trays of Incense and Flowers for the Ten Directions**
The ritual states: Incense, in its essence, communicates and purifies, dispelling impurities. Flowers, in their fresh purity, outwardly and inwardly manifest preciousness. When petitioning for blessings and invoking the Perfected, flowers and incense are fundamental. Flowers may be fashioned from five-colored silk to pacify the ten directions—none may be omitted. Any deficiency is examined by the Bureau of Yang Officials.

**Two *Hu* and Four *Dou* of Rice**
The ritual states: Rice substantiates trust before the Celestial Officials and augments official emoluments. Any deficiency is examined by the Bureau of Celestial Officials.

**Two *Dou* and Four *Sheng* of Oil**
The ritual states: Oil is of the yin category; within yin, yang is born. Pacifying with oil ensures yin continues the radiance of yang. Any deficiency is examined by the Bureau of Yin Officials.

**One Hundred Twenty *Jin* of Charcoal**
The ritual states: Charcoal is of the yang category; within yang, yin is born. Pacifying with charcoal ensures officials are endowed with yin *qi*. Any deficiency is examined by the Bureau of Yang Officials.

**Twenty-Four Thousand Cash**
The ritual states: Fourteen thousand cash in gold and silver substitute for the pledge of superior gold, substantiating sincerity before the Three Realms and proclaiming the covenant to the Ten Heavens. Any deficiency is examined by the Bureau of the Mystic Capital.

**Hibiscus Wood Tablets**
Three tablets, each one *chi* and two *cun* in length, two *cun* and four *fen* in width, and two *fen* in thickness.
The ritual states: Tablets serve to record and proclaim. They record the merit of the age and proclaim the covenant to the Supreme Perfected, aligning above and below. The Son of Heaven uses jade, for jade possesses the Nine Virtues, signifying the trust of Heaven and Earth. Now, tablets are demarcated with cinnabar to correspond to the Five Phases. Ministers use hibiscus wood in place of jade. Any deficiency is examined by the Bureau of the Nine-Nine Earthly Officials of the Ministry of Earth.

**Gate of the Reed-Enclosure Dragon Officers**

The Dao in its essence is a single qi, pervading the space between heaven and earth. That which is above form is without substance or direction; that which is below form has objects and images. Thus, the great method of the *Lingbao Scripture of Salvation* establishes the Reed-Enclosure and Cold Forest, along with the Dragon Officers, all of which embody objects and model images.

Since humans live between heaven and earth, some sink into delusion, losing their original good heart, and thus fail to fulfill their natural lifespan. After death, they stagnate and do not transform, becoming what are called "lonely souls." Without the true method of the Great Dao to gather and transform their deluded karma and illusory deeds, restoring each to their original nature, how else could heaven return their hun and po?

Therefore, the Reed-Enclosure and Cold Forest symbolize the nine provinces and their corresponding celestial regions. The Dragon Officers who restrain the souls of the dead are modeled after the principle of ascending transformation, guiding consciousness to transcend, reaching the farthest azure heavens and penetrating the deepest yellow springs, conveying sincerity without limit. Moreover, when one’s own dragon and tiger are refined, guarded, and perfected, one rides the yang to ascend. Thus, when one person is delivered, all souls are delivered; when one nature is illuminated, the myriad heavens are fully bright—this is the meaning here.

Whenever a grand fast is established, a Reed-Enclosure must be constructed to broadly deliver the souls of the dead. It may be made of reeds or pure thatch, following the principle of city walls. Eight gates are arranged, each with a placard, and eight gate banners are displayed, corresponding to the celestial regions. Banners of the Nine Provinces’ Earth Deities are raised, and a great measuring vessel is set in the center. Alternatively, forty-nine small vessels may be arranged, with two banners of Sweet Dew and Precious Nectar on either side. A water basin is placed in front, into which iron talismans and petitions are submerged. A large talisman plaque is also set up, along with two seal-script petitions.

When the banners and canopy are erected at the gates, the master transforms into the Heavenly Worthy of Salvation from Suffering, assuming ten forms to receive and guide all beings. Each day, the assembled Daoists take turns performing rituals to distribute Dharma-food. During the main fast, incense is offered and scriptures are recited—all these are urgent tasks for delivering the dark realms and must not be omitted.

To Fly the Spirit and Petition the Emperor’s Gate

The subtlety of the Dao lies in the clarity of one’s nature—this is called "stillness without motion." The transformation of spirits and the numinosity of dharma are called "response through resonance." The principle of stillness and response encompasses both essence and function, and thus cannot be attained through mere instruction. Unless one has mastered the art of moving without obstruction and parting or uniting with natural ease, who could achieve this?

Therefore, the Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure possess the method of *Flying the Spirit to Petition the Emperor*. It begins with daily cultivation of the Cinnabar Origin and the Red Child, gradually refining them until one can soar through the Great Void with effortless freedom. Only then may one present memorials and submit petitions.

The method of *Six Jia and Nine Spirits Flying Steps* requires that on the day of the corresponding Jia hour, one begins by stepping toward the direction of the Green Dragon—this is the Living Gate of Heaven. Next, traverse the Star of Mugwort, pass through the Hall of Light, ascend to the Great Yin, and summon the Six Ding Jade Maidens. Then rise to the Heavenly Gate, invoke the names of the gods guarding the current gate, proceed to the Earthly Door, and fly into the Heavenly Treasury. Returning, step through the Six Geng, call forth the Jade Maidens, and enter the Inner Heavenly Gate. From the Dipper’s handle to its bowl, pay homage to Wenchang, tread upon the Three Terraces, turn to bow before the Heavenly Sovereign, and step back to align with the Five Stars. Then, ascend the Nine Spirits, prostrate in reverence, command the spirits to hasten, and present oneself at the Primordial Court to petition the Emperor. Thus, one harmonizes with the auspiciousness of life and prosperity, concealing one’s form and vanishing from sight, ascending directly along the Yellow Path.

The altar for this rite is called the *Nine Spirits Flying Steps Memorial Jade Altar*, and its presiding deity is the Cinnabar Origin Lord—one’s own primordial spirit. The nine numinous spirits are named: *Wandering Light*, *Heavenly Path*, *Jade Hall*, *Void Brahma*, *Primordial Yellow*, *Purple Radiance*, *Flourishing Spirit*, *Heavenly Seclusion*, and *Spirit Perfection*. These nine embody the pure yang of Heaven’s qi, while their numinosity lies in the wondrous transformations of spirit and illumination. It begins with directing the spirit to merge with the Dao and culminates in forgetting form to nurture emptiness, where nature and Dao become one, responding to circumstances with resonant communion.

If one has not yet attained profound subtlety, one must focus on cultivating the heart-mind. When the method of the heart-mind is also illuminated, one naturally harmonizes with the Dao. Thus, "humans can magnify the Dao, and the Dao is not distant from humans." With prolonged practice, one swiftly attains the utmost subtlety. How can the method of *Flying Steps* not be approached with utmost care?

**Ritual Instructions of the Heavenly Master**

*Annotation:* In the opening of memorials, there are references to the *Dao Above*, the *Two Mysteries*, the *Three Origins*, the *Four Beginnings*, the *Lords of Jiazi*, the *Four Quarters*, the *Five Quarters*, the *Seven Quarters*, and the *Nine Quarters*—what gods are these?

*Answer:* The *Dao Above* is the Lord of the Great Dao of Non-Action, who resides before the Three Powers; hence, it is called the *Dao Above*. The *Two Mysteries* are Heaven, the *Three Origins* are Humanity, and the *Four Beginnings* are Earth—these are the designations of the Three Powers: Heaven, Earth, and Humanity. The *Lords of Jiazi* are the gods of the twelve earthly branches and heavenly stems. The *Quarters* refer to the spirits of the land, plants, mountains, rivers, marshes, and lakes.

*Regulation:* In worldly memorials, the phrase "awaiting your report" has become customary through habitual use, but this is due to errors in transmission. How could a subject, when entreating the Emperor’s command, use the phrase "awaiting your report"? It should be amended.

*Regulation:* According to the *Orthodox Unity Ritual Regulations*, twelve small seals are used to stamp the beginning and end of memorials in the Year of the Grand Year Star, deeming it appropriate. However, these memorials are originally drafted at the end of the year or season, using a general memorial to submit to the Heavenly Bureau, after which these twelve seals are applied. According to the memorial rites of the Han Heavenly Master, memorials were never burned or stamped. When presenting a memorial, the spirit ascends to the Heavenly Bureau, and upon the efficacy of the matter, these twelve seals are submitted to the Heavenly Bureau. For ordinary memorials, they should not be used. Some have examined esteemed precedents in this manner, and scholars should carefully consider this.

*Regulation:* The language of worldly memorials should begin with a formal introduction, yet nowadays, only the phrase "respectfully according to the document" is used. The ancients employed parallel prose to introduce the intent of the memorial before entering the main purpose of the rite. Later generations, not understanding this, hastily adopted these four words from ancient texts, greatly deviating from the original meaning.

*Regulation:* When writing a memorial, leave three blank lines after the Grand Year (Tai Sui). This signifies that upon the memorial’s arrival at the Heavenly Bureau, the names of the officiating day’s memorial petition, the three-fold titles of the memorial, and the Heavenly Master’s office with the Great Clarity (Tai Qing) title are recorded. The three blank lines thereafter signify that the Spirit Consort of the Dipper, officiating on that day, presents the memorial to receive the Supreme Dao’s decree, which is inscribed therein. The three lines below "prostrate twice and depart to report" signify that the Celestial Palace’s Keeper of Treasures, the Jade Emperor’s daily myriad-transformations treasure, is used to make the report. The three lines bearing the minister’s surname signify that for this memorial, the officiating Dharma Master, should they bear the ten evils, five rebellions, or other transgressions, is vouched for by the Heavenly Bureau’s Four Offices. These four matters are all standard protocols of the Heavenly Bureau.

*The Supreme Perfected’s Mysterious Model* states: In households where death occurs, regardless of age, a woman in childbirth remains in impurity for one hundred days. Entering the chamber of a woman in childbirth incurs impurity for three days. For the death of a child or servant, impurity lasts one month. For the death of livestock, impurity lasts one day. When outside, there is no impurity period for mourning, but forty days apply. For major mourning of silk and hemp, impurity lasts one month; after the month passes, it is lifted. Visiting a mourning household to weep incurs impurity for that day. Prolonged mourning carries no impurity. Mourning household feasts, food for a woman three days postpartum or at her full month, must not be consumed. For all the above impurities, one must not establish fasts, erect altars, or present memorials and petitions. If in another place, resolve impurity with talismans.

*Regulation:* The host of a memorial or altar rite must not kill living beings. Violators will have their lifespan reduced by twelve years. Memorial and altar offerings must not be borrowed from others. Formerly, Master Red Pine asked Zuo Pingchang, the Keeper of the Heavenly Gate: "Previously, at the *wei* hour of a *ji* day, I presented a memorial—why has there been no response?" Zuo replied: "The day before, I saw the Jade Maiden bearing incense arrive, but the Heavenly Gate was closed, so she departed. Thus, there was no response." Master Red Pine further asked: "The twelve double-hours of day and night—may I hear the method of the gate’s opening?" Zuo Pingchang said: "Yang days in yin hours, yin days in yang hours—these are the open times. On yang days in yang hours, presenting memorials harms livestock. On yin days in yin hours, presenting memorials kills people or harms distant travelers, for the Heavenly Gate is closed."
