*Lingbao Jade Canon*, Scroll Eighteen: *Flying to the Divine Gate to Petition the Emperor*
*The Nine Numinous Flying Pace Petition Method*

According to the transmission of the Supreme Perfected of the Southern Culmen, Controller of Destinies, Lady Wei of the Orthodox Origin: during the Jin dynasty, the Female Official Libationer and Orthodox Unity Celestial Master, Lord Zhang, received *The Great Clarity Petitioning the Offices Rites* and the *Entering the Retreat Method*. Moreover, since the Han era, the matters of the One Thousand Two Hundred Offices have been transmitted in correspondence, and it is fitting to uphold and employ them. Additionally, the Orthodox Unity Petition Regulations recorded in the Jade Casket, the Red Pine Treasure Register, the Jade Almanac, and the inner and outer talismanic contracts serve as established methods. After Master Du of the Broad Accomplishment of the Tang dynasty compiled and arranged the *Proclamation of Compassion Petition Texts*, these were scattered and lost due to warfare, and complete versions are rare. Now, when petitions are to be presented, there is no fixed format. Recently, due to the mediocrity and recklessness of later scholars, arbitrary additions and omissions have been made, rendering them unfit for use. Furthermore, the offices and ranks are disordered, the formats are inauthentic, the petitions fail to reach their intended destination, and the acts of reverence do not accord with the profound principles. This is not due to the lack of sincerity in the fasting officials’ hearts but rather to the extreme difficulty of obtaining worthy adepts. If petitions are presented carelessly, it is as if casting them into the void, inviting reprimands and punishments—truly lamentable and grievous.

Therefore, after profound reflection and hidden inquiry, consulting the numinous texts, eliminating the superfluous and extracting the essential, simplifying and returning to the source, I have compiled and arranged these writings to assist the *Five Origins Jade Registers* in transforming and praising, instructing and teaching the learners of the true, and aiding both the living and the deceased. The purport of the *Nine Numinous* method is to be received separately with the true rites. Such matters as the *Great Clarity Entering the Retreat Oral Petition* are not to be fathomed by ordinary talents. Their forms communicate with the true and reach the numinous, their spirits ascend the jade steps, and even the immortal officials may not necessarily adhere to them. Yet how can the Three Caverns’ Daoists, libationers, and disciples neglect these profound and secret mysteries? Upon reading the texts, one should awaken in heart and mind and carefully attend to them. Take care not to leak them lightly. Those who receive and transmit them must petition the Three Heavens, offering nine pairs of gold rings and ninety feet of azure silk, swearing an oath before bestowing them. They may not be transmitted more than three times in a lifetime. Those who violate this will suffer death and the destruction of their families—beware!

**Thirty Articles of the Three Caverns’ Mysterious Regulations**

When a master presents a petition on behalf of the common people, the documents must not be left scattered or delayed among mortals. All should be collected and recorded, and all matters within a year should be addressed. Daoist followers must not record them.

Petition cases should be one foot and five inches long, one foot wide, and eight inches high, with curved legs, and made of cypress wood.

Petition caskets should be one foot and two inches long, four inches square, with an additional inch in intercalary months. The measurement should be based on the middle joint of the master’s middle finger; glue must not be used. The casket should have an opening at the bottom.

For presenting petitions, separate incense and fire must be used; one must not use fire or ashes from the kitchen hearth.

For the method of presenting petitions of gratitude and apology, face north, with all household members, young and old, loosening their hair and crossing their hands to request the petition.

Curved-leg cases should be used for presenting petitions. Other stools are unsuitable, as they prevent the petitions from being spiritually received.

Petition caskets should be sealed with an imprint and labeled according to the method. Others are not suitable for presentation.

During the presentation of petitions, those in the household of the offering official must not create disorder with loud voices, nor should chickens or dogs startle and bark, lest the spirit-*qi* be unsettled and the petition fail to ascend.

When a master presents a petition on behalf of an offering official, there should be ritual tokens and merit offerings of delicate items. It is hoped that illnesses will diminish and cease, and that entanglements and obstacles will be resolved. On the day of receiving grace, one may accept ritual tokens and alms.

Those who violate this will be treated as thieves and punished according to the six penal codes, liable for three thousand tiles and bricks.

When a master officiates in presenting petitions to save the sick or deliver the common people from calamity, if people urgently seek help for grave illnesses and the master remains at home under false pretenses or fails to attend to the emergency, the offender will suffer ten days of illness as punishment.

Incense stands should have a base, be two feet and four inches long, one foot and six inches wide, and two feet and four inches high, sufficient to support the petition case.

The paper for writing petitions must be pure and clean, without holes, tears, or uneven edges, and should not have fewer than three lines remaining at the end. If insufficient, use whole sheets. Otherwise, desist.

The small characters on the petition should be one inch and two fen long, with four fen extending beyond; otherwise, they are unsuitable. Small characters refer to the Great Clarity precinct.

When presenting petitions for the chief transgressions of offering officials or for private and secret matters, one may petition in the retreat, burning the petition words directly. The matters must not be publicly declared or disclosed to others. Revealing them to the netherworld authorities is a grave offense.

For petitions, whether large or small, exposed or indoor, all should be retained for three days. The case must not be immediately dismantled, the seat removed, or the petition hastily burned. If in doubt, burn it.

When presenting petitions in the retreat, the superior position faces east. If there are matters to be exposed, all face north.

On the Three Assembly Days and Community Days, one must not present routine petitions or memorials. For urgent matters, the three-eight-day solar apologies are not prohibited.

From three days before to three days after the Winter Solstice, one must not present routine documents or petition writings. Urgent matters are not prohibited.

On the days of *wuxu* and *wuchen*, one must not rashly enter the retreat. If it is the fifteenth day of the month or a Three Assembly Day, one must not perform morning audiences. The Three Assemblies have separate petitions for changing the day; the words and sections for Community Days are suitable for presentation but not for the Assemblies.

On the three days of the Three Assemblies, one should report merits. If there are matters on those days preventing presentation, one may present them afterward without omission.

When register initiates present petitions themselves, they may orally state what they wish to say.

When receiving grace, one must personally declare one’s merits and virtues, which are then conveyed to the original master for retention. The original master’s distant conveyance is for the sake of proximity. If a master presenting a petition consumes mutton or wine, their foul breath entering the retreat will forfeit three thousand merits. When the officers and soldiers return to the Heavenly Bureau, if your petitions are empty for a hundred days, the throne will not hear them. One must not drink wine in the home of the sick, lest a hundred ghosts hide within the person’s body. If the illness is not cured after healing rites, the petition will not be received. When a master presenting a petition encounters illness, they must save and sustain the person’s life. If one harbors prior enmity and wishes death upon another, the misfortune will rebound upon oneself.

When disciples present petitions on behalf of their master, they should begin by stating on this day: "Your servant, so-and-so, the master I follow." If, while a disciple presents a petition for their master, there is urgent illness in the household, they must withdraw and request leave, not stopping at mere verbal acknowledgment. If there is no urgent illness, this is unnecessary.

When writing petitions, use clean brushes and inkstones, and hold the petition with the petition table as part of the ritual; only then may it be prepared. Do not drape the petition over one’s body or place it on a bed, lest the petition go unheard and merit be lost through labor and error.

For the rites of a *jiao* official presenting a petition, one must burn incense, enter the fasting chamber, bow, and request permission to present one’s case. One must not rashly carry the petition into the retreat without proper announcement, as this is like casting it into water.

For the method of presenting the *Luxing* Petition to the Supreme, one must burn incense, enter the retreat, and request the incense officials and messengers to bring the incense burner into the courtyard. One must not rashly enter the retreat to retrieve it, as this fails to properly address the Perfected Officials. If one merely carries the incense burner out while in the retreat, there will be no attendants or guards, demonic spirits will interfere with the petition, the myriad spirits will be wearied, and the paper and ink will be wasted, for there is no proper rite of invitation.

When presenting the *Luxing* Petition, there must be lamps, each with a dipper, and each dipper must have its *kuigang*. When the *gang* intersect, one must be cautious of the *gang*. Do not break the stars by misaligning them, and do not easily instruct others in this; beginners must be cautious.

When *jiao* officials face the petition, they must all face north. If there is urgent illness, they must go on foot, with hair unbound and hands clasped. If there is no such urgency, this is unnecessary.

The Mysterious Capital has its palaces and bureaus, each with its own overseers.

When Daoist petitions are submitted, if they reach the celestial audience but contain errors, deviations, or losses of the true Dao, with disordered sequence or misalignments that violate heavenly statutes, they will be rejected by the celestial bureaus, the matters will fail to reach the throne, and the unknowing petitioner will vainly entrust their hopes, believing the petition has been received. When the matter fails, they will claim the Dao is without efficacy, never attributing the fault to the Daoist—how grievous this is. If the petition conforms to the statutes and commits no transgressions, all ailments treated will be cured, and all lives saved will be preserved.

**Petition Writing Regulations**
The height of petition paper should measure one *chi* and nine *fen*, or, by the smaller standard, one *chi* and two *cun*, or one *chi* and four *cun*. Each sheet should have twelve lines, or some say nine lines, with seventeen characters per line. Alternatively, one line may span the entire width. Each line should be one *cun* and two *fen* wide, or two *cun* and four *fen*. In the *Zhengyi* method, leave an eight-character indentation. In the *Taixuan Du* protocol, the first line of the official title should be indented by one character, approximately two lines in length. Ancient methods did not specify indentation, or allowed three lines, aligning with the yang number of the Three Powers.

The first line should conclude the ritual title, followed by "prostrating twice and respectfully submitting," with an eight-*fen* indentation above and a continuous line of "ant-walk" script below. The ritual title should be one character higher than the "respectfully submitting" line. Ensure the text aligns precisely, with the lower section’s language concise and the name written in a single unbroken character—no splitting allowed, as in cases like "so-and-so, née Ji." The character *chen* (臣) must not begin a line, nor *gui* (鬼) head one. Avoid placing characters denoting life or death in prominent positions. Terms like *hunpo* (魂魄) or references to death must be avoided at the start of lines.

One *cun* below "prostrating twice," write "to be heard," and for the concluding line, begin a new row. The *Xiuzhen Zhiyao* follows this, while Cai Zhixu’s ritual places the characters *gaobao* (告報) below "to be heard." After "to be heard," leave three lines blank before writing the petitioner’s surname. After the surname, leave another three lines blank before writing the *Taiqing* rank. Following this, leave three more lines blank before writing "Minister [Name], subject of the Great Year," aligning with the "Great Year" line. Two *cun* and four *fen* below "respectfully submitting," begin writing. The "Great Year" line should be evenly spaced to reach the end of the row. Adjust the margins at the start and end of the paper, adding a sheet if too short.

The *Taiqing* rank consists of fifty-six characters, written in compact, fine script. The upper section measures three *cun* and six *fen*, the middle four *cun* and five *fen*, and the lower five *cun*, not exceeding these dimensions. This follows the ancient statutes of Master Red Pine. For forty-eight characters, write them in three *cun*. In the *Xiuzhen Zhiyao*, omit the four characters *Jinque Qibao* (金闕七寶), resulting in fifty-four characters. Since discrepancies exist, careful verification is required.

Petitions must not be written across days, and "Your Majesty" must not be filled in across different times. Ancient methods required filling in *Taiqing* without delay. The characters *Bixia* (陛下) should be written finely in a single line, like the *Taiqing* rank. Some suggest writing only these two characters finely, but *Bixia* is a term of respect and should not be split. Writing them separately may appear unstable. Neither the *Wulian Shengshi Jing*’s yellow-silk petition method nor the Zhang-Du *Eryi* texts address this. Thus, write them finely in a single line.

**Heart Petition Format**
The statutes state: Heart petitions are only for submitting matters and must not be verbose; the words must convey the intent directly. For submitting to the *Xuwu Ziran Yuque* method, use yellow silk measuring one *chi* and two *cun* in length and three *cun* and six *fen* in height, written densely in fine cinnabar script. Leave a three-*fen* margin above and one *fen* below, with no fixed number of lines. Leave blank space at the start of the petition for the *Huangshen* seal and at the end for the *Yuezhang* seal. Seal it with a leak-proof closure, not a square box. During prostration, visualize the process according to the *Chaoyuan* method.

For the first prostration, hold the petition and bow. For the second, present the petition and orally state its intent. For the third, visualize the Celestial Worthy’s disposition of the matter. When burning, use the *Lingbao* Heart Mantra in a large incense burner. Such petitions are submitted urgently and receive a response within an hour. Those without merit may not submit them.

"On the [day] of [month] in the [year], after fasting and purification, with reverence and awe, prostrating twice, I respectfully submit: Your servant, based on the matter at hand, humbly invokes the Left and Right Dragon-Tiger Lords, the Incense-Bearing Golden Youth, the Jade Maiden Transmitters, the Incense Official Envoys, the Three *Qi* Orthodox Spirits, the *Qi*-Hastening Merit Officers, and the Flying Petition Attendants."

**Alternative Format**
The statutes state: Heart petitions follow the *Taiqing* format, with a length of five *cun* and six *fen* and a height of three *cun* and two *fen*. Using the middle joint of the middle finger as a measure, each line contains seventeen characters, and each sheet must not exceed twelve lines. For *Yuqing* and *Shangqing*, use yellow silk with cinnabar script; for *Taiqing*, use ink, though urgent matters may be written in cinnabar, all in three grades.

*Yuqing* uses the *Feixuan Sanqi Yuzhang* seal; *Shangqing* uses the *Taishang Santian* seal, the *Jiuling Feibu* seal, and the *Taiqing* seal; *Taiqing* uses the *Huangshen Yuezhang* seal. Regardless of urgency, seal it securely without a square box. Such petitions receive a response within moments.

**Seal Protocol for *Zhengyi* Petitions**
The statutes state: The *Zhengyi* Dao of the *Taiqing* was transmitted by the Supreme Sage of the Mysterious Origin to the Celestial Master of the Orthodox Unity. For the rite of petitioning, the *Nine Elder Immortals of the Xian Du* seal is employed, as the Eight Elders of the *Taiqing* revere the Supreme Venerable as their master. Thus, disciples submit their memorials to their master, hence the use of the *Nine Elder Immortals of the Xian Du* seal.

Additionally, twelve smaller seals are used, from the *Tai Xuan Du* to the Grand Year, all to be impressed on the reverse. Some traditions include a border following the seal format, while others omit the border, resembling a talisman. This should be determined by careful consideration.

**Petitions of the *Dongzhen***

**Petitions of the *Dongzhen***

The statutes state: The *Dongzhen* rank pertains to the Dao of the *Yuqing*. It emerged during the Yonghe era of the Jin dynasty, transmitted by the Seven Perfected—Three Mao, Two Xu, Yang, and Guo—without a fixed format for memorials and petitions.

**Seal Format for *Dongxuan* Petitions**

The statutes state: The *Dongxuan* Dao is the teaching of the *Lingbao*. Its doctrines existed as early as the era of the Three Sovereigns. Originally, there was no fixed format for petitions, as seen in the *Scripture of the Five Refinements for Animating the Corpse* and the *Original Conduct of the Five Elders*, differing from the methods of standard petitions. When performing *Dongxuan* rites, the petition should have blank space before and after, with talismans inscribed according to the prescribed form. Only the *Tongzhang* seal is applied above the date. Since the *Yuchen* is a disciple of the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning, this seal serves to convey sincerity to the ancestral master. Those not ordained in this register may not presumptuously use its seal script. The *Shenxiao* register also employs it. Some claim this seal belongs to the *Yuqing* and the *Dongzhen* department, unaware that before the rise of the *Shenxiao* teachings, *Dongxuan* petition methods from before the Five Dynasties all used this seal. The *Tongzhang* seal is in fact the *Great Charter for Ascending to Heaven*, merely omitting its lower text. The living use it as proof for ascending petitions into the celestial courts. When bestowed upon the deceased, it includes summons for the soul and related matters. The *Great Charter for Ascending to Heaven* has, from ancient times to the present, clearly belonged to the *Dongxuan* department—how could it be ascribed to the *Dongzhen*? The current use of the *Tongzhang* seal in *Dongxuan* petitions follows the original statutes of the *Lingbao*. If another seal is substituted where this one should be used, it must be reviewed by the Three Officials.

**Format for Yellow Silk and Vermilion Petitions**

The statutes state: Use twelve feet of yellow silk, backed with light yellow silk and cut to a height of one foot two inches. Each line contains twenty-four characters, with a line width of one inch two *fen*, or nine *fen* as a standard. If following ancient methods, one line measures two inches four *fen*, but this may be impractical for lengthy texts; adjust the number of lines according to the word count. Since the petition is called *huangsu* ("yellow silk"), raw yellow silk should be used. Master Tian, finding it too soft for handling, recommended backing it with thin paper for ease, then inscribing in vermilion. The dimensions, whether height or width, generally follow the petition format. Seal it in a round fold, with an inner and outer square envelope, both made of yellow silk. The outermost layer bears the supplicant’s surname in plain script. The fifth northern panel holds the supplicant’s surname, aligned with the Grand Year. The sixth northern panel contains the *Taiqing* forty-eight characters, written in three-inch script. The seventh northern panel holds the year, month, day, and hour, followed by "respectfully submitted from [such-and-such] prefecture, village, and hamlet." The eighth panel leaves three blank panels for the Three Masters’ spiritual praise; if insufficient, use additional paper to fill them. The ninth panel marks the petition’s boundaries with eight-part regular script on the top margin, while the central margin is divided according to the method of measurement. The tenth panel follows the above method for petition formatting, without arbitrary margin adjustments.

The decree states: Daoists of the *Zhengyi* tradition must adhere to the ten regulations above when inscribing petitions. No arbitrary margin adjustments or personal innovations are permitted, lest they mislead later learners. Violators who devise their own methods shall be judged under the five penalties of the *Zhengyi* Daoist code. The fifth penalty entails repairing thatched roofs with three thousand bundles of straw.

When the master writes petitions or memorials, he must first purify himself through fasting and ablutions, rinse his mouth, wash his hands and face, adjust his robes and cap, enter the oratory, face the Heavenly Gate to arrange his seat, burn incense, click his teeth, swallow his saliva, and clear his mind of all extraneous thoughts. He then spreads a clean cloth upon the table and visualizes the Azure Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, and Black Tortoise guarding the four directions. Next, he burns incense, grinds ink with forty-nine circular motions, and passes the brush through the incense smoke. He recites the incantation:

May this servant attain long life and present his petition to the Jade Clarity.
May all evil vanish and demonic forces be severed.
Those who violate this petition shall be punished by the Northern Emperor.
Hasten, as decreed by the statutes!"*

*Register for Ascending to Heaven*
Method states: When inscribing the register, face east, burn incense, and visualize the *Jade Dawn Emperor*, performing the rite with proper intent.
Next, recite the register’s sacred title, grinding cinnabar eighty-one turns left and right.
Then draw the *Azure Mystery Qi* into the cinnabar.
When inscribing the register, first recite the *Scripture of the Numinous Treasure* once, then kneel and invoke:
*Your subordinate, [Name], with reverent trepidation, bows head to ground in prostration.*
Petitioning the *Three Clarities*, the *Three Realms’ Great Dao*, the *Compassionate Honored One*, the *Central Heaven Emperor*:
*Your subordinate petitions on behalf of the intent herein, humbly beseeching the granting of deliverance.*
*Your subordinate now inscribes the register in accordance with the formula, entreating the descent of celestial grace to aid below, the flow of true qi, the unsealing of the writ, and the bestowal of the register for inscription and distribution as prescribed.*
*May the nether prisons cease their sorrows, and the dead souls receive deliverance.*
*Your subordinate’s heart is overwhelmed with fervent devotion, to the utmost of earnest prayer.*
Next, perform nine bows, visualizing the *Heavenly Gate* opening.
The *Heavenly Gate* is a triple-gated golden portal, resplendent with golden light, within which stands a golden palace hall.
The *Jade Dawn Emperor* sits enthroned therein, flanked by attendant perfected ones arrayed around the imperial seat.
Present the preceding matters, and the Emperor’s compassionate countenance brightens with joy.
By imperial decree, the *Golden Lads and Jade Maidens* bear the treasure casket, descending through a hundredfold radiance to the writing desk, merging with the prepared register.
Light lingers above, boundless and inexhaustible.
Next, face south and perform nine bows, silently petitioning the *Southern Dipper*.
Visualize the six stars, each vast as the solar wheel in its rising aspect, converging and descending to merge with the six stars of the register, each star bearing a distinct character within, fully luminous and transparent, their brilliance unified.
Next, offer incense and strike the teeth twelve times.

*Within is the immortal spirit who delivers the dead,*
*Within is the Southern Culmen’s Lord of Longevity,*
*Within is the Great Spirit Sima who delivers the world,*

**Purport of the Vermilion Mound’s Refinement and Mysterious Directive—**
The master sits in tranquil repose, calming the hundred cares. Within the Mud-Pill Palace atop his own head—the Celestial Abyss of the Heavenly Valley—light illumines within and without. There, the Heavenly Worthy of Great Unity sits upon a throne of gold and jade, clad in azure robes, vermilion slippers, a cloud-wrought crown, and holding a jade scepter. A halo encircles his neck, and golden lotuses bear his feet. Presently, the Heavenly Worthy radiates the luminous brilliance of a hundred treasures, illuminating the eight directions.

Then, with one’s own nature, one ascends to pay homage to the Heavenly Worthy, reverently reciting his sacred name. Suddenly, purple qi descends from the palace like threads, settling into the cinnabar field, coalescing into a luminous orb the size of a pellet, resplendent in purplish-gold. Let one’s nature ever abide within the Heavenly Valley atop the crown, never allowing it to scatter.

In the midst of this true visualization, the form is suddenly forgotten, stillness pervades, and clarity extends above and below. Whether walking, standing, sitting, or reclining, one may cultivate this practice. This is the Dao of refining form and spirit to attain unity.

When the purple qi enters the cinnabar field, it naturally generates the true fire of radiant essence—this is the work of primordial yang qi. As it is said: *When the Great Unity resides in the head, the myriad spirits pay homage.* The divine luminaries stand guard with mighty power, subduing all demonic and malevolent forces, which dare not oppose.

When spirit and qi flourish, illness vanishes forever. Whatever is sought or undertaken shall be instantly answered. For it is by refining qi with spirit, and spirit with form, that both form and spirit attain perfection, and the body merges with spontaneity. Gathering the myriad methods into the One True, dispersing the One True into the ten thousand scenes—no longer bound by existence or non-existence, forever transcending birth and death—this is the True Person.

Those who receive this method shall burn incense, face east, and kneel in reverence. Visualize one’s true nature, disclosing past and present transgressions and karmic errors. Release the nine generations of ancestors and the seven lineages of forebears, masters and fellow disciples, as well as all offenses in both yin and yang. Universally extend this deliverance to the six paths and four modes of birth—winged, crawling, submerged, and hidden—all shall be transformed and liberated.

Humbly beseech the Heavenly Worthy to bestow compassion, responding to devotion and effecting communion. May the minister’s heart be at peace, qi flourish, the spirit-chamber radiant, and the mysterious merit be accomplished. May no demonic trials arise, and may all ascend to the Realm of Eternal Joy, merging with the Dao in truth.

Thereafter, inscribe the talisman.

*Scripture of the Jade Mirror of the Numinous Treasure, Scroll Twenty-Nine*

The Illumination of the Gates of Darkness

When the primordial qi first divided, the Two Modes took their places. Yin, as the heavy and turbid qi, congealed into earth; yang, as the light and pure qi, floated into heaven. Where yin and yang intermingled and fused, the harmonious blackness of the Center coalesced in man. Thus, the nurturing of the Three Powers and the generation of the myriad transformations arise from nothing but the wondrous flow of the one qi.

Moreover, human nature is originally pure, luminous, and subtly wondrous—empty, penetrating, and spiritually communicative. Hell and heaven are utterly non-existent. Yet due to differences in nature and habit, human desires sprout and grow. From thought arises emotion, from emotion accumulates karma, and as karma encounters circumstances, it manifests accordingly, leading to sinking or rising in accordance with retribution. Thus, those of good kind belong to yang, while those of evil kind belong to yin. Therefore, the affairs of heaven and hell are truly brought about by a single thought of good or evil.

Hence, in the great methods of the Numinous Treasure, there is the principle of lighting lamps to break open hells and deliver the stagnant and rescue the hidden. This must first begin with the inner arising of mysterious illumination, to brighten the originally wondrous and non-existent wisdom-lamp of heaven. Then, one illuminates the inherent awakened nature of all beings, causing lamps to connect in succession, inwardly and outwardly pervading with clarity. Thereby, the innocent are released, goodness is pursued, and transgressions are distanced. Then, in an instant, one transcends and is transformed within the domain of the lofty, bright, upright, and great, suddenly awakening to the originally pure and natural Dao. Where then are the so-called roots of sin and evil karma? Hell and heaven alike return to emptiness and quiescence. Yet how can one not be cautious of thoughts of good and evil?

Each altar’s four corners curve thrice, resembling a prison’s shape.
Three lamps burn brightly at each prison, twenty-seven lamps in all.
At the heart of each prison, erect a tablet facing its direction. Inscribe upon it the *Talisman for Breaking Hell* and the *Dharma Gate of the Offering Ritual*, with the prison’s name written on the reverse. Suspend nine banners above.

The Nine Dark Realms reside in the central palace of the Eight Trigrams.
According to the divisions of the Nine Provinces, each is overseen by local deities.
In Heaven, they are the Nine Heavens; on Earth, the Nine Palaces; their transformed forms become the Nine Dark Prisons.
Their names are nine, yet all arise from a single *qi*, a single thought’s resonance.
For every evil thought of the deceased, a prison manifests, and retribution follows.
Thus, the Most High, in boundless compassion, established this ritual offering to deliver the suffering souls. Know well its origin.

If the rite is small in scale—failing to honor the sovereign and all under Heaven above, or to deliver the nine ancestors and the six paths below, but only saving one or two souls—how could the Celestial Emperor issue a special pardon, opening all Nine Prisons for a single person? Such a thing is impossible.
Not all hells can be shattered, nor all dark souls delivered.
If one’s intent lacks even the slightest merit of benefiting others, it contradicts the ritual’s true purpose.
For private offerings, lighting lamps and reciting praises—or constructing nine cups of lamps—suffices.
The *Rite for Breaking Prisons* need not be performed, lest one commit presumption and blasphemy.
A filial child repaying a parent need only exhaust sincerity in repentance—how could one assume their ancestor *must* have fallen into hell and thus perform this rite? Such is the principle.
If one truly wishes to proceed, adapt the ritual as circumstances allow: prepare offerings of grain, deliver the sunken souls, and build merit according to one’s capacity. Then, the *Breaking Prisons* rite may be performed without impropriety.

For countless suffering souls, lost in delusion, a single misguided thought may consign them to prison for eternity.
Without beseeching Heaven’s decree, enacting talismans, and breaking the dark realms, how could they find liberation? Thus, follow the method precisely.

**The Jade Origin Pursuit and Deliverance Gate**

The Dao’s capacity to encompass the cosmos and nurture the myriad things arises entirely from the wondrous workings of spontaneity—how could it ever involve retribution? Yet with beings, it is otherwise. The qi that dwells within form is but fleeting dust, and from the moment a thought of good or evil arises, retribution inevitably follows.

Thus, the Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure include the *Jade Origin Pursuit and Deliverance* protocol, specifically for delivering the souls of those who died in childbirth or blood-related deaths. Given that their karmic entanglements have already accumulated and the conditions for retribution swiftly follow—drowning them in the rivers of desire and seas of craving—how much more so when they fall into gestation, suffer bodily harm, or perish in blood and filth? The stench of their defilement defies description.

Though their physical forms may be gone, their lingering attachments remain unextinguished. Therefore, they must be cleansed in the pure, vast source of the Forest of Judgment, washing away the stains of their past impurities. Through the light of true yang and perfect goodness, their original nature is awakened. The Purple Essence clarifies their Dao, and the Jade Talisman transports their spirits.

Thus, their illusory karmic bonds and phantom shadows dissolve like fallen blossoms, while their wondrous true bodies shine like the moon in the sky—utterly unobstructed, equal to the vast emptiness. How could this not be beneficial?

The Master says: The Gorge Stone Prison lies in the southeast of the Iron Enclosure. There stands a great stone, broad above and tapering below, with a narrow fissure at its center. Ghosts who enter it are naturally drenched in a hundredfold of poisonous juices, tormenting their bodies and minds. To the north of this prison is the Blood Lake Great Prison, the most defiled of all. Within it, women who died in childbirth endure suffering for countless kalpas—an agony beyond measure, truly pitiable.

When delivering the souls of those who died in blood or childbirth, one must first dispatch talismanic commands to the specialized officials overseeing childbirth, who will purge the filth and transform the Blood Lake. Only then may the deliverance proceed. The pardon must be memorialized three days prior, and only after its completion may the rites of summoning and gathering commence.

Upon arriving at the ritual arena, the Dharma Master must first perform the purification of defilements and petition the Heavenly Physicians for healing. Only thereafter may the souls sequentially receive offerings and precepts. If one merely performs a generic pursuit and deliverance without discernment, there will inevitably be places the talismans cannot reach—this must be carefully heeded in practice.

Summoning the Gate of Hidden Spirits

The nature of the Dao is equality, vast and unbounded—augmented yet not increased, diminished yet not diminished. Near yet not proximate, distant yet not remote. Gathered into one, it is not lacking; dispersed into ten thousand, it is not excessive. Be it heaven, humanity, sages, or commoners, there was never any difference. Yet sentient beings, gradually stained by karmic consciousness, drift from their origin and root. A hair’s deviation becomes a thousand *li* of error. Thus, the noble and the base diverge sharply, the common and the sacred stand worlds apart, and myriad distinctions arise between self and other.

Therefore, the Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure possess the principle of summoning and gathering hidden spirits. Through divine power and majesty, they universally deliver heaven and humanity, yet still fear that beings in all destinies may remain mired, never fully realizing the mystery of the Dharma-nature. Thus, with the pure and spontaneous wondrous light of the Numinous Treasure, they universally gather and deliver, so that the ten directions become unimpeded and the myriad realms perfectly fused. Then the sage and the common within the heart, heaven and earth within the nature, the vast and the minute become one, without lack or excess. This is the wondrous meaning of the True One, non-dual—how could it be otherwise?

**The Gate of Arrayed Pavilions for Dispensation and Transformation**

The body of the Dao resembles emptiness, yet it contains all and transforms all—how could it be confined to a single corner? Consider how the moon emerges in the heavens: wherever there is water, its reflection is present without fail. Or how thunder resounds upon the earth: wherever it is heard, its echo responds without exception. The nature of the Dharma is likewise—still and empty, it can respond to all things. If one extends the mind of constant goodness to save beings and things, its transformative power will reach everywhere without limit.

Thus, the obstructions of sentient beings obscure their original luminosity. The eye-root clings to phenomena, turning to manifold defilements and creating karmic conditions. In life, they suffer invasion by illness, leading to injury, premature death, or incomplete forms—none attain their rightful destiny. Though the body perishes in death, deluded thoughts persist. Therefore, through the great methods of the *Lingbao*, a dispensation is arrayed: by the wondrous transformation of the Primordial Beginning, their original nature is restored. Heavenly karma and karmic consciousness are severed, wholesome roots flourish—what illness, distress, or suffering could remain?

As the scripture says: *"My great affliction is that I have a body. When I no longer have a body, what affliction remains?"* Now that the body is empty, illusory, and dissolved—like clouds dispersing to reveal the bright moon—no longer clinging to the dust of form, no longer entangled in the transformations of the ten thousand conditions, how could this be discussed in words or captured in writing?

**Gate of Ritual Bathing and Robing**

The waters of the Flowery Pond originate from the essence of the Great Yin in the Eastern Well, their ebb and flow attuned to the sea’s tides. The source runs deep and the flow endures long—nothing exists without reliance upon water.

Yet when a person’s form has perished and their *qi* has dispersed, what substance remains to be bathed? Truly, it is because the stains of passion and desire accumulate gradually, the grime of karmic defilement obscures the clarity of the mind. What one is tainted by in life persists even in death, for the threads of worldly thought remain unsevered.

Thus, the grand rites of the Numinous Treasure tradition prescribe the ritual of bathing: internally, one mobilizes the true water of Heavenly One; externally, one prepares the orchid-scented broth of the five fragrant herbs. The Crimson Dragon stirs the source of White Stone, while the Great Mystery guides the *qi* of Yellow Blossom, washing away old impurities and reopening the primordial heaven of the departed.

When the five aggregates are empty, the five turbidities are all purified; when the one mind awakens, the ten thousand conditions are wholly cleansed. Only then may one don unstained robes and wear indestructible garments, embodying the true within the formless form, paying homage to the Three Treasures in the heaven within heaven. Such wondrous communion with the mysterious workings defies all conjecture.

**Gate of Transmuting Dharma-Food**

All myriad methods arise from the mind and likewise perish within it. That which gives me life is spirit; that which slays me is the heart. Thus, when one savors the wondrous meaning, one comes to know the heart’s function—its benefits and harms are beyond enumeration.

In the beginning of human life, one is but the dwelling of a single spirit, yet to possess this heart. As the Four Great Elements provisionally coalesce, spirit congeals into heart, and the heart, with spirit as its dwelling, gradually drifts from its origin. Once the heart departs from its origin, thoughts arise in its wake. With the first thought’s attachment, a hundred actions follow. From these hundred actions, the ten thousand conditions sprout forth. Therefore, when this thought arises, if it inclines toward goodness, one becomes a celestial immortal, a human sage, or a divine spirit; if it inclines toward evil, one becomes a denizen of hell, a hungry ghost, or a beast. This is no other cause but the direction of a single thought.

Moreover, in the vast expanse of the great earth, all that possesses form and appearance is inevitably bound by the thought of hunger and cold, which persists even unto death. Thus, the Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure include the section on delivering the hidden shades, embodying the compassion of the Dao to awaken all sentient beings. Through food, the Dharma is enacted; through the Dharma, the mind is illuminated. Once the mind-Dharma is clear, what hunger or thirst remains? Therefore, this method fulfills such thoughts, casting aside delusion to return to truth. The so-called Eight Assemblies and Five Kitchens, the ambrosial nectar of ghee, the fragrant viands and precious delicacies, the jade-like liquors and crystalline essences—all are inherently present within the Dharma-body. This nature is complete in itself; why seek externally? What may be sought externally is but illusion. One must clearly recognize the great origin, deeply savor non-action, forever escape the wheel of rebirth, and realize the supreme Dao. If this principle is understood, how could it merely deliver the hidden shades?

The Gate of Severing the Corpse and Transcending the Five Portals

In the great methods of the Numinous Treasure, there exists the Dao of "Severing the Corpse, Transcending the Five Portals, and Consigning the Celestial Spirits to the Treasury." Thus the scripture states: "Invoke the extinction of the Three Evils, sever the root of earthly bonds, soar through the Five Portals, and inscribe your name in the Supreme Mystery." The Three Evils and Five Sufferings all arise from habit and this heart, which is truly the origin of all karmic misdeeds.

Now, humans receive life from the qi of the axes and the Five Phases, inherently luminous and pure, free from defilement. Gradually, as the human heart drifts from the root toward the branches, it pursues delusion and loses the real. The bitter retributions and evil affinities revolve endlessly, drowning one in ceaseless torrent, forgetting the way back. To return to the origin becomes impossible.

Thus, one must rely on the wondrous Dao of purity, stillness, non-action, and spontaneity to awaken the unawakened nature—indestructible and unadulterated. With a firm and sharp blade, sever the unsevered affinities, enabling one to trace the current back to the source, return to truth, and awaken to the root. This is called "emptying the Five Aggregates," whereby the Five Sufferings naturally dissolve. Realizing the wondrous Three Origins, the Three Evils naturally vanish.

Thereafter, assume the form of the Great Dipper’s Celestial Pivot, uniting the true qi of the Two Forces and Five Phases. With the numbers of heaven-and-earth’s generation and completion, revert to the original numinous essence of the Great Cavern. Whether called "heaven" or "spirit," all enter the primordial treasury of the Origin’s radiant light, returning to the Ultimate of Non-Being. Hence, it is called "consigning to the treasury." What further reflection is needed?

Then, with a mind of resolute firmness, wield it as a sharp sword to sever the Three Corpses. The left hand seals the jade script, while the right brandishes the sword. Next, with a single qi of golden light, guide and escort the deceased soul to soar through the Five Portals. At the moment of practice, if not a single thought arises, all affinities naturally diminish.

The **húnshén** (soul-spirit) clears and rectifies,
Ten thousand **qì** eternally preserved.
No suffering or torment endured,

The Three Realms attend in guard,
The Five Emperors oversee the welcome.
Ten thousand spirits pay homage,
Their names inscribed in Heaven.
When virtue is complete and power attained,
Ascend to the **Shàngqīng** (上清, Upper Purity).

Swallow the saliva three passes,
After a while, the image of the **túxiàng** (图象, divine diagram) emerges at the nape,

Invoke:
The **Wúshàng Xuányuán** (无上玄元, Peerless Primordial),
The **Tàishàng Dàojūn** (太上道君, Supreme Way Sovereign).

The **Tàiyǐ Sīmìng** (太乙司命, Grand Ethereal Overseer of Fate),
**Táokāng Héyán** (桃康合延, Peach and Immortality united),
**Wúyīng Gōngzǐ** (无英公子, Peerless Noble Son),
**Bái Yuánshén Zūn** (白元神尊, White Primordial Spirit Venerable),
I now refine the **zhēnyuán** (真元, true essence) within,
Its light illuminating the Nine Heavens,
Dispelling the **Yángjīng** (阳精, yang essence),
Piercing the Nine Gates,
Thus the departed soul receives refining,
Returns to the womb and is reborn,
Form and spirit both perfected,
Harmonizing with the **Dao** (Way) and true verity.
Draw the fire-*qi* through nine mouths to swallow,
The spirit’s light appears measured,
Piercingly illuminating the **Yōumíng** (幽冥, dark realm).
This preceding practice is preserved and applied,
Daily perfected in tranquility.

Four inches and five *fēn* (分) wide,
Five inches and five *fēn* high,
Mix **xiónghuáng** (雄黄, realgar) and **zhūshā** (朱砂, cinnabar) evenly,

All recite the **Lónghàn Dàngdàng** (龙汉荡荡) incantation,

Piercing the **Wěilǘ** (尾闾, tail sluice),

Write the **□** (晅, *omission*) character on the eastern Sun,
Draw the pen downward to the **tiān** (天, Heaven) character above,

Draw the **qì** from the **xīn** (心, heart) to blend with Yellow,
Returning to the **Dàntián** (下丹田, lower elixir field),

Piercing the **Shàngníhuáng Gōng** (上泥丸宫, upper mud pellet palace),

All riding the **Jīnguāng** (金光, Golden Light),

My original true nature is indeed the **Fǎshēn** (法身, Dharma Body).

With spirit merging into *qi*,

Like **liúlí** (瑠璃, crystal) reflecting the infant.
Repeatedly recite the **Lónghàn Dàngdàng** incantation,

Summoning the **Yīngshì** (将吏, officers) to refine the soul’s fire,
Preserve the **Huǒ Dàjiāngjūn** (主火大将军, Commander of Fire).

「引魂入火沼受炼，即引右天罡字中，曳笔过於此，中念 **南方之君**咒。 在火炼符后 左手寅文，火炁引吹於火中，魂神澄正。
　　念 **龙汉荡荡**咒。 存众魂冉冉长大，具足形相，天衣飞坠。 众魂皆得服着。

　　次舌柱上腭，化为法桥，引魂随笔上升，至右天罡字涂上。
　　念： **元始符命**，时刻升迁。 亡魂受度，立便生天。

　　及三天讳四字，存金光中有朱陵火府，众魂皆升其中，咸得超生。

　　**灵宝玉鉴**卷之四十：**召主火大将军内炼符午文南炁**。
　　高功再入火炼科。 知磬举**玉眸炼质天尊**，谨召主火大将军赵仲明，速至坛所，合炁炼魂。
　　右神红袍金介，冑绿仙带，自南方乘云而至。

　　师吸炁归中，化作金**罡**字，以**阳斗诀**发此字於火沼中，光明洞焕，如天边晓日之状，受炼众魂，俱入日中，**玉眸炼质**。
　　咒曰：
　　**阳晶阴耀**，洞焕五行。
　　随符降炁，冶炼阴魂。
　　**知磬举玉眸炼质天尊**。

　　高功鸣召主火大将军，立降真火，冶炼亡魂。
　　**立降真火符** 右符寅加卯，卯交寅，风火交，午文，出南炁三息，存日中丹华金光，化为流火神庭，冶炼亡魂。
　　众和**玉眸炼质天尊**。
　　**宣主火咒**：
　　南方主火神，驾景掷火铃。
　　奔飞耀南枢，交炁媾生津。
　　炎晶流金光，冶炼阴死魂。
　　复归**元始炁**，再返天地根。
　　流金以减奸，邪秽悉然焚。
　　洞观无碍法，自得保真身。
　　**玉符召主将**，急急速来临。
　　**太玄妙炁**，主掌炎烟。
　　造化玄炉，**真魂陶埏**。
　　主火成胎，景象自然。
　　变炼阴户，准令上天。
　　急急如律令。

　　入火沼正炼，移婶於火沼边。
　　**火炼正符午文南炁** 咒曰：
　　**南阎洞浮**，流火之庭。
　　**玉眸诜诜**，流火之膏。
　　刀利禅猷，婆尼灵童。
　　流火之质，**玉眸真容**。
　　升入福堂，洞阳之宫。

　　**太阳火炼符午文离炁** 咒曰：
　　南方之君，**赤炁**之精。
　　荧惑使者，**丙丁将军**。
　　朱雀炎神，赫赫**阳晶**。
　　五行造化，万类发生。
　　天帝有勑，**光彻幽冥**。
　　急急如**太阳帝君**律令。

　　**火炼血尸符午文南炁** 咒曰：
　　**玉眸炼质**，拔度幽冥。
　　玉文一下，**炁魂飞升**。
　　**玉眸炼质符** 咒曰：

　　**太一炼质**，九步八魁。
　　行罡七转，**内外合成**。
　　三台子午，**绛宫受真**。
　　符炼万灵，**赤火降心**。
　　辟除恶毒，往来俱荣。
　　北都曲府，**离合上清**。
　　大洞自然，**风火无停**。
　　**日光炼神符太阳炁诀** 右符存合**童阳君**，日光紫色，叩齿二十四通。
　　咒曰：
　　**阳晶**已通，飞光已新。
　　皇芝流溢，**荫注内缠**。
　　仰餐流晶，**芳华未臻**。
　　宫宅开张，**荡洗嚣尘**。
　　体映玉光，**面发金真**。
　　云飞禹步，**上造日册**。
　　急急如**太阳帝君**律令勑。

　　**火九炼返生符** 九道 一符午文**日光** 咒曰：」

The Most High Daoist *Fanqi* Talisman-Jewel Method: Ancestral Qi Master’s Ritual of the Wandering Banner and Exchange-Refinement

**Incantation:**
Heaven One begets Water—*hai* enters *zi*, Earth Two begets Fire.
*Yǐ* enters *wǔ*—Water and Fire exchange, refine.
From *zi* to *wǔ* and back to *zi*, naturally perfecting the True.

The Talisman’s inner resonance—threefold in its operation.
Recite the incantation for the third time.

**Subsequent Incantation:**
Within the True lies the God—Long-Life Great Lord.
Without the Noble Prince—White Primordial Venerable God.
Taiyi the Life-Director, Peach-Kang the Longevity-Bearer.
Wielding the Talisman, clutching the Registers—preserve life, root the essence.
Ascend the Upper Flow, enter the Pure Abode, traverse the Flowered Chamber.
Within the Eight Obscurities, in the minutest depths.
Descend to govern the mortal form—Muddy Pellet’s Crimson Palace,
harmonizing the Five Qi, blending the Hundred Deities.
Ten revolutions restore the Soul—ten thousand Qi become Immortals.

Burn the Banner, transform into the Immortal Banner.
See the Banner cover the Gate.

The Master, tongue propped against the upper palate,
draws the Ancestral Qi from the center down to the Lower Dan,
passing the Tail Gate, ascending to pierce the Muddy Pellet,
transmuting into the Primordial Sovereign Emperor.

Recite inwardly the Middle Section once—
the Heart and Kidney Qi intermingle,
Water Pool and Fire Marsh refine,
purifying form and spirit, both entering the Cavernous Yang’s flowing fire,
burning away the embodied self from birth onward—
all reduced to ash, preserving only the Essence.

Next, within the ash, a faint thread of True Qi remains,
like a dew droplet—
the One Extremity before the Great Polarity,
the harmonious Nature.

*'The Five Emperors transform into Immortals,
*Qi* gathers as **Qian** [Heaven].
The departed soul receives refinement,
Jade light pierces the Mysterious Void.'

**Great Dao Salvation Celestial Sovereign**
*The resonance of **Zhen** refined into the **Jing Talisman***
Incantation:
*'The Compassionate Sovereign of Salvation,
Liberates the lost souls.
Through this refinement, they endure through all kalpas.'

**Precious Flower Fulfilled Celestial Sovereign**
*The radiance of **Dui** refined into the **Shen Talisman***
Incantation:
*'Form and spirit both attain perfection,
Uniting with the light to become Immortal.
Virtue and power complete—
Ascending to the Nine Heavens.'

**The Master Says:**
*'For the Yellow Register Rite, use nine talismans invoked in sequence.
Write the talismans in red on yellow paper,
The notification in black.
Enclose them in a case as prescribed,
Each talisman corresponding to its Celestial Sovereign.*

**Nine Talisman Invocation Format**
*Within the prescribed sequence, the essence of flowing water is refined into the **Pao Talisman**,
To be substituted as per the talisman’s order.*

**Positioned in the Legal Order:**
*Subject, [rank] [title] [surname] [given name]*
*Respectfully [offering] [ritual object], established in the [year/month/day].*

**Supreme Yellow Register Great Rite of Universal Salvation**
*To rescue and liberate the souls of [certain individuals], freeing them from the Underworld and ascending to the realm of the living.*

Now, with reverence, we invite the **Three Pure Ones** to preside,
and the myriad saints to oversee,
following the celestial registers,
and performing the alchemical refining.

In accordance with the prescribed rites,
we submit the talismans for registration and invocation.
We humbly pray that the **essence of flowing water** be refined into the **Pao Talisman**,
and that all **true talismans** be duly issued and proclaimed.

**Blank Talisman**
*Rightfully, the臣 respectfully submits,
following the talisman’s order,
and presents it for supreme alchemical refining before the **Celestial Sovereign of the Dan Domain**.*

With deepest reverence, we await the **Dao’s compassion**,
to bestow special grace and mercy,
granting vital *qi* to nourish [certain souls].
Thus, the departed souls may undergo refining,
transforming into immortals and becoming true humans.
The living bodies receive salvation,
eternally enduring through the eons.
With the revolving of the kalpas,
they align with Heaven’s lifespan,
forever transcending the **Three Realms of Suffering, Five Torments, and Eight Hardships**,
soaring to the **Upper Clarity** in boundless freedom.

The臣’s humblest devotion is filled with trembling awe.
Respectfully submitted.

**Year of the Celestial Stem [Year]**
**Month [Month]**
**Day [Day]**
*Submitted by the臣 of rank [rank], surname [surname], awaiting decree.*

**Day-Soul and Moon-Spirit Talismans**
*Through water and fire’s transformation into immortality,*
the talismans are unified as one.
Each, after refining by water and fire,
is used in sequence—
once the refining is complete,
a new birth arises without form,
requiring no further reliance on water and fire.

All **Juling Degree-of-Life talismans** and others
are hereby granted—
no need for repetition.

**Incantation for Revitalizing the Soul**
*God-True and boundless in wonder,*
the primordial essence of transformation.
Left, the **Seven Spirits** are held,
right, the **Three Souls** are bound.
The **Twenty-Four True Ones** restore the yang essence.
Refined by flowing fire,
purely crystallizing into **Yuying** [jade essence].
Ascending to the **Southern Palace**,
adroitly soaring in **Juling**.
Morning, drinking the sun’s radiance,
evening, racing with lunar essence.
Bathing in the **Eastern Well**,
treading upon **Dan Clouds**.
Attending the **Golden Gate’s court**,
feasting in the **Jade Capital**.
With spirit perfectly attuned,
uniting with the Dao’s True Essence.

**Talismans:**
*Juying God-Transformation Talisman*
*Jue Ancestral Qi*
*Receiving the Dao with the Yellow Robe—Treasure Edict Ancestral Qi*
*Jade Text*
*Lingbao Mystic Altar*

This month, **on the day of the fast**,
the **Chief of the Fast** [certain] humbly establishes the **Supreme Vow**—
the **Jade Essence Treasury** and **Yellow Robe** for the **Great Liberation Rite**,
spanning several days and nights.
Following the **Mystic Techniques**,
all **meritorious deeds** are performed.
I pray to open the liberation for the soul of **certain**,
elevating it to the **Celestial Realm**.

With the current **refinement of the departed soul**,
all the **Treasure Edict Ancestral Qi** [from the Yellow Robe Dao-receiving talismans]
are solemnly declared to those below.

**Primordial Beginning** opens the **Linked**,
the **Great Mystic** initiates the **Sacred**.
At **Void’s extremity**, no form exists—
**One Qi** flows into all shapes.
**Transformation** generates **Two Lands**,
the **Five Halos** condense **True Essence**.
Blending with **Nature’s spontaneity**,
it eternally dissolves the **Fetal Spirits**.
The **True Essence** spreads its **Lands**,
radiant and resplendent in the **Nine Pure Ones**.
**Flaming** holds **Luminous Splendor**,
the **Seven Epochs** align in harmony.
The **Luo Teacher** [or **Luo Master**] and **Lu浩** [Lu’s vastness] are divided—
the **Dan Heaven** shines with crystal clarity.
**Jade Light** refines and liberates,
**Red Luster** disperses with brilliance.
The **Three Splendors** flourish luxuriantly,
illuminating the **Imperial Star**,
just as the **Lingbao** [Numinous Treasure] Sutra liberates countless souls with its **Mandate**.

The **Year, Month, and Day** are recorded below,
along with the **Chief’s name, rank, and lineage**.
The **Right Talisman**—five *chi* of yellow paper inscribed in **Jade Script**—
is bound and sealed,
then burned in the **Qi-Concentrating Furnace**.

**Knowing the Celestial Chime**,
the **Golden Gate’s** **Embodied Celestial Sage** raises his **Form**.
The **Assembly proclaims the Great Incantation**—
**Fluid Mystic Qi** condenses the **Sacred Root**,
the **Jade Text** gathers all **Spirits**.
In the **Void’s expanse**, the **Natural** swells vast,
above are the **Twelve Layers of the Lingbao Transmission**.
The **Jade Tower** stands grand, radiating **Lands of Splendor**,
**Flowing Essence** and **Purple Gate** encircle the **Golden Pavilion**.
The **Crystal Hall** gleams with brilliance around the **Eight Directions**,
within are the **Nine Sacred Spirits of Azure-Gold**.
The **True Mother of Jade-Yellow** is named **Jingyan** [Essence Extension],
wearing **Flying Azure** feathers and a **Morning Infant’s** crown of jade.

She holds the **Jade Node** and grasps the **Sacred Banner**,
the **Five-Colored Soul Demons** bow before the **Imperial Sage**.
With talismans and scriptures at the **Gate of Life**,
she chews the **Sun** and swallows the **Moon**, drawing from the **Liquor Spring**.
**Luo** dispels radiance, refining the **Five Souls**,
filling the **Palace of Crimson** with joy.
**Golden Light** blazes resplendently, the **Form** perfectly rounded—
from **Azure** to **Mystic**, the **Color** pure and unblemished.

Only the **Enlightened** understands these words,
on the **Day of the Northern Primordial**, the **Tenth of the Fifth Month**.

The **Celestial Canopy** leads the **Celestial Lord of the Fast**,
**Purple Qi** swirls leftward with the **Fighter’s** movement.
Passing through **Four Sevens**, entering the **Golden Gate**,
it is the **Dan Emperor** who inspects the **Ten Thousand Celestial Beings**.

If one **masterfully recites** this **Incantation** with **diligence**,
the **Form** will be **unveiled**—
each thought will be **divided** and **ordered**.
The **Wondrous Lands** will respond,
the **Essential Text** will be **received**—
in **three years**, one must **guard** and **preserve** to ensure longevity.
In **nine years**, ascending the **Void** and treading the **Clouds of Splendor**,
wearing the **Phoenix Garments**, lightly soaring to **Dragon Mountain**,
bowing to the **Nine Sacred Spirits** and greeting the **Jade Infant**,
one becomes a **Lingbao Great True Sage**.

**Talismans:**
*Talisman of Celestial Transformation into Human*
*Double-Handed Jade Incantation, Ancestral Qi*

**Proclaiming the Thirty-Heaven Great Vow**,
a separate **technique** is applied at the **Gate of the Yellow Robe** for **Dao-receiving Talismans**.
The **High Master** performs the **Law of Ascension and Liberation**,
reciting inwardly the **Jade Scripture**,
declaring the **Mandate of Longevity**.
The **Dao Assembly** chants in unison—
the **departed soul** undergoes **refinement**,
**transforming into a celestial being** and becoming **human**.
The **living body** receives **liberation**,
and **eon after eon** will endure.
With the **Wheel of Eons**, it turns in harmony,
and **lifespan aligns with the heavens**.

**Permanent Liberation from the Three Realms and Five Torments, Eight Hardships**,
transcending the **Three Realms**, freely wandering in the **Upper Pure**.
The **Celestial Sage of Adroit Joy** is raised.

**Jade Pure Celestial Gate Talisman of Life and Birth Transformation**
*Jade Incantation, Ancestral Qi*
The **Incantation** says:
*"The Primordial Jade Scripture,
preserves and liberates the departed soul.
Ascending to the **Jade Palace**,
directly to the **Celestial Gate**.
The **Demon King** pays homage,
the **Ten Thousand Saints** protect and welcome.
The **Jade Pure Primordial Mandate**,
freely wandering in the **Upper Pure**.
As swift as the **Primordial Beginning’s** **Law of Liberation**."*

**Talisman of the Law Bridge for Life and Birth**
The **Right Talisman** calls forth the **Azure-Yellow-White Three Qi**,
to be burned at the **time of sending the departed**.
The **Incantation** says:
*"The **Celestial Sage’s** mighty and sacred power,
opens the **Dao’s Light** in all **Eight Directions**.
Leading the **Seven Departed Souls**,
ascending this **Law Bridge**."*

The **two eyes** remain **interlinked**,
**Purple Light** and **Dan Clouds**,
above corresponding to the **Celestial Sage’s** **Treasure Pearl’s Light**,
below connecting with the **departed soul**,
ascending to the **Celestial Realm**.
The **Master** pinches the **Three-Five Soul-Calling Incantation** and dispatches it.

Next, **concentrating the spirit** in the **Great Desert**,
neither **form** nor **void**,
if present or absent,
with **nothing** to cling to,
naturally attaining **Dark Profound** and **Piercing Clear**,
the **Great Compassion** of the **Mystic Void**.

Next, **sending the departed**,
burning and **offering**,
**merit transfer**.
**Refinement and Liberation Altar Formation**

The **Lingbao Jade Mirror Scroll** concludes at the **forty-third section**.

chunks.original_text: 玉婴神变符　　披黄受道宝诰 仙化成人符 玉清生化保度天门宝符 生天度命法桥符 炼度坛式附坛心式 灵宝玉鉴目录竟 灵宝玉鉴卷之一 道法释疑门 灵宝斋法释疑 《灵宝经法》之卷首，有四译、八明、七经、八纬，已备诸家之说，姑摭其大纲如左。 四译 《灵宝经》法，自玉宸道君得黍珠所授，赤书玉字，八威龙文，上天所宝，不传下世，此译之一也。 道君叙其神通变化，冠之经首。 叮咛学者笃信力行，於经之后，此译之二也。 道君撰灵书中篇，而天真皇人昔书以为正音者，此译之三也。 西汉元封中，西王母以是经授之武帝，遂译大梵之言为神州之语，天篆之字为同文之书，此译之四也。 其后老君历代降世，其传浸广汉天师，诸仙递相授受。 汉光和二年，太极真人徐君来勒，以授太极左仙翁葛真君玄，仙翁授之上清真人杨君，皆汉元封已译，无所再译，其有五译之说者，皆赘言也。 八明 一、当明灵宝者，即元始祖炁。 其初溟津大梵真炁，自无而有，一切有象有形，皆由是气而生成，所谓成象成形者，又各有是气也。 亦儒家所谓一物一太极也。 故人受中以生，则亦各有是气焉。 祖之为言先吾父母而生者也。 於我身求之，则父母未生之前，此气在何处。 我身内之父母，复是何物。 我由而生，所谓无相之我，又在何处。 当如此究竟，然后入无出有，与道合真。 二、当明元始敷落五篇，赤书玉字，八威龙文，经法中一应符篆，皆始於此。 学者当究其妙，则其功用如经所云。 三、当明《灵宝经法》皆出於混洞赤文。 混者，二五合凝之未兆也。 洞者，无色无渊之谓也。 由是而化生诸天，开明三景，五文开廓，普植神灵，变化无穷矣。 四、当明《灵宝经法》乃万法之宗。 自五劫开化之后，三洞四辅诸经诸箓，总而三十六部，支而万八千篇，故自老君流传於世，灵宝之品独多。 五、当明人之有生，无极太极。 吾其性二气五行，吾其体一点灵明。 炯然 不昧者，则合性与知觉，谓之心也。 学者当常常存其心，养其性，明则为命世之圣贤，幽则为遗世之神仙，济利幽明，特其余事耳。 六、当明灵宝妙用。 如太极真人曰：常於太极握枢机，动静神珠照幌帷。 就里分明灵宝现，如悬黍米在浮黎。 然后随所运用，变化无穷矣。 七、当明省身悔过，念道思真，毫发邪念不留於心，视听言动常如对越。 八、当明真修实践，日积阴功。 凡遇月月失昏，星宿错度，四时失序，阴阳不调，疫毒流行，兵革四兴，水旱虫蝗等，皆当依经旨修禳，以母负玉宸道君之垂训，自然优入道域，与道合真，身得神仙，亦分内事。 七经 一曰大定神光，一点灵明，如如不动，大而六合，微而秋毫，皆在吾神光中。 二曰洞观微视，圣日圣月照跃金个庭，光映十方，无阴不烛。 三曰内服玉札金书，皆诸天日月星斗天真大神亿讳隐名，有诸中则神凝炁充，施诸用则神动天随矣。 四曰采炼祖气，以生圣胎法身。 夫谓祖气者，人人具足，不假外求。 学者当朝夕存思，守而勿失，真积既久，乃成圣胎。 然后见所谓法身，出有入无，神功妙用，与造化同流矣。 五曰五行内炼。 诀曰：五行顺则生人，逆则生丹，一豪情欲之萌，即耗真气学者常当吐烛纳清，收视返听，使五行真气攒簇於神室之中，无顷刻间断，可以长生久视，可以济显度幽，神动则气随，无施不可也。

**Scroll One of the *Numinous Treasure Jade Mirror*: Daoist Methods Clarified**
**Clarifying Doubts in Numinous Treasure Retreat Methods**

At the head of the *Scriptures and Methods of the Numinous Treasure*, there are Four Translations, Eight Clarifications, Seven Scriptures, and Eight Latitudes, which encompass the doctrines of all schools. Here, we briefly extract their main principles.

**Four Translations**
The methods of the *Numinous Treasure Scriptures* were first received by the Jade Emperor Dao Lord from the Millet Pearl, inscribed in vermilion script on jade with the Eight Might Dragon Script—treasures of the heavens not transmitted to the lower world. This is the first translation.
The Dao Lord recounted its divine transformations and marvels, placing them at the scripture’s beginning. He exhorted scholars to cultivate steadfast faith and practice, appending this to the scripture’s end. This is the second translation.
The Dao Lord composed the middle section of the *Numinous Writ*, which the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign of Old transcribed as the correct pronunciation. This is the third translation.
During the *Yuanfeng* era of the Western Han, the Queen Mother of the West transmitted this scripture to Emperor Wu, translating the great Brahmā’s speech into the divine land’s language and celestial seal script into unified writing. This is the fourth translation.
Thereafter, Lord Lao descended through successive generations, its transmission gradually spreading. In the second year of *Guanghe* of the Han, the Supreme Ultimate Perfected Xu Junlai transmitted it to the Supreme Ultimate Left Immortal Elder Ge, the Perfected of Mystery. The Immortal Elder transmitted it to the Shangqing Perfected Yang Jun. All were translations from the *Yuanfeng* era, with no further translations. Those who speak of a fifth translation merely add superfluous words.

**Eight Clarifications**
First, one must clarify that the Numinous Treasure is the primordial ancestral *qi*. In the beginning, the vast and boundless Great Brahmā’s true *qi* emerged from non-being into being. All that has form and image is generated and completed by this *qi*. That which forms images and shapes each possesses this *qi*—akin to the Confucian notion of "one thing, one Supreme Ultimate." Thus, humans receive the center to live and each possesses this *qi*. "Ancestral" signifies that which precedes our parents’ birth. Seeking within the body, one must ask: where was this *qi* before the parents’ birth? What are the "parents within the body"? From what was I born? Where is the formless "I"? Only by thoroughly investigating this can one enter non-being and exit being, merging with the Dao in truth.

Second, one must clarify that the *Primordial Beginning’s Unfolding of the Five Chapters*, the vermilion script on jade, and the Eight Might Dragon Script—all talismanic seals in the scriptural methods—originate from this. Scholars must delve into its mysteries, and its efficacy will align with the scriptures’ proclamations.

Third, one must clarify that the *Scriptures and Methods of the Numinous Treasure* all derive from the *Crimson Text of Primal Chaos*. "Primal Chaos" (*hun*) refers to the unmanifest coalescence of the Two and Five. "Abyss" (*dong*) denotes the colorless and boundless. From this, the myriad heavens are transformed, the Three Luminaries illuminated, the Five Scriptures unfolded, and divine spirits universally planted, their transformations endless.

Fourth, one must clarify that the *Scriptures and Methods of the Numinous Treasure* are the origin of all methods. After the Five Kalpas of unfolding transformation, the Three Caverns and Four Supplements encompass thirty-six divisions of scriptures and registers, branching into eighteen thousand chapters. Thus, since Lord Lao’s transmission to the world, the Numinous Treasure’s corpus has been uniquely vast.

Fifth, one must clarify that human existence arises from the Limitless and Supreme Ultimate. Our nature is the Two *qi* and Five Phases; our body is a single point of numinous clarity. That which shines unwaveringly unites nature and consciousness, called the heart. Scholars must constantly preserve the heart, nurture their nature, and in brightness become sagely worthies of the age, while in obscurity become transcendent immortals beyond the world. Aiding and benefiting the hidden and manifest are but secondary matters.

Sixth, one must clarify the wondrous functions of the Numinous Treasure. As the Supreme Ultimate Perfected said:
*"Always at the Supreme Ultimate, grasp the pivot’s mechanism,
In movement and stillness, the divine pearl illuminates the curtained chamber.
Within, the Numinous Treasure appears distinctly,
Like a millet grain suspended in Floating Blackness."*
Thereafter, its applications are boundless in transformation.

Seventh, one must clarify introspection and repentance, contemplating the Dao and pondering the Perfected. Not a single deviant thought should linger in the heart; sight, hearing, speech, and action should always be as if in reverent attendance.

Eighth, one must clarify true cultivation and sincere practice, daily accumulating hidden merits. Whenever the moon wanes at dusk, constellations misalign, the four seasons fall into disorder, *yin* and *yang* lose harmony, pestilence spreads, warfare erupts on all sides, or floods, droughts, and locusts arise, one must perform expiatory rites according to the scriptures’ injunctions, lest one fail the Jade Emperor Dao Lord’s teachings. Naturally, one will excel in the Dao’s domain, merge with the Dao in truth, attain immortality, and fulfill one’s destined role.

**Seven Scriptures**
First: *Great Stabilization of Divine Radiance*. A single point of numinous clarity, immovable in suchness. Vast as the Six Directions, minute as an autumn hair—all reside within one’s divine radiance.

Second: *Penetrating Vision of Subtleties*. The sagely sun and sagely moon illuminate the golden courtyard, their light pervading the ten directions, dispelling all darkness.

Third: *Internal Ingestion of Jade Tablets and Golden Scripts*. These contain the hidden names and secret appellations of the myriad heavenly sun, moon, stars, constellations, and celestial perfected. When held within, spirit congeals and *qi* flourishes; when applied, spirit moves and heaven follows.

Fourth: *Refining and Cultivating Ancestral Qi to Generate the Sagely Embryo and Dharma Body*. "Ancestral *qi*" is possessed by all, requiring no external pursuit. Scholars must constantly contemplate and guard it without loss. With genuine accumulation over time, the sagely embryo forms. Thereafter, one perceives the so-called Dharma Body, exiting being and entering non-being, its divine functions and wondrous applications flowing with creation.

Fifth: *Internal Refinement of the Five Phases*. The formula states: "The Five Phases in sequence generate humans; in reversal, they generate the elixir." The slightest sprouting of desire and passion depletes true *qi*. Scholars must constantly exhale the turbid and inhale the pure, withdraw vision and return hearing, gathering the Five Phases’ true *qi* within the spirit chamber without a moment’s interruption. Thus, one may attain longevity and eternal vision, aid the manifest and deliver the hidden. When spirit moves, *qi* follows—nothing is beyond its application.

chunks.original_text: 六曰黍珠神化。 吾身自有始青天浮黎土，黍珠一颗不用外求，当知此理散之则弥满六合，敛之则不盈一握。 七曰中理五炁，混合百神。 学者当常常持其志，以养其气，使之归於元海，听命於我之元神，则随所设施，混合百神也。 八纬 一曰流精玉光，乃上天精粹刚正之气，天之灵宝也。 学者当於身求之，存养之久，必见所谓五色郁勃，洞焕太空。 施之於用，则无所不辟，无所不禳，无所不度，无所不成矣。 二曰洞阳符火。 按《灵书》中篇六十四卦之炁运，以混合三十二天之真炁，行之积久，与道合真。 三曰大行梵气，一切真仙，莫不由此超度。 经曰：大行梵气，周回十方，学者能使身中梵炁周流，无一息间断，则度人之功，诚为无量，生身受度，亦余事也。 四曰三宫修诵，三宫即三田也。 先当持戒制情，正心诚意，真炁内固，然后诵经，则婴儿升降，三田随声念诵，其功德力亦如经旨矣。 五曰报本返始。 学者必於三元、八节、五腊，诸先亡讳日，依教诵经，以尽报本返始之道。 春秋祭祀，亦当随家丰俭为之，庶几为人，行报本之道，无愧也。 六曰九品阴功。 经曰：星宿错度，日月失昏，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 四时失序，阴阳不调，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 国主有灾，兵革四兴，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 疫毒流行，兆民死伤，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 师友命过，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 学者当於此力行，以积阴功。 功德积累，则诸天书名，鬼神敬服，济生度死，随念皆符，身得神仙，皆不外此。 七曰玄灵济度。 学者□ 当於清夜，朝礼北斗，依法咽服元皇正炁，求所谓太玄之一，守其真形，然后身有光明，魔无干犯，运神会道，随念感通。 八曰济度无间。 经曰：常行善心。 又曰：齐同慈爱。 凡见鳏寡孤独，疾病饥寒，便当思以济之。 若己乏财力，则广行劝化。 如凶年饥岁，沟壑死亡，兵戈扰攘，僵尸暴骨，吊祭不至，精魂无依。 当依经法，随力拯救。 则亦功沾先远，庆及见存。 太极仙翁，萨真人，路真官，历代祖师，皆於此用心，以不负经旨也。 奏申关牒文字论 斋法之设，必有奏申关牒，悉如阳世之官府者。 以事人之道，事天地神祇也。 所以寓诚也。 是假我之有，以感通寂然不动之无也。 然后见其洋洋乎，如在其上，如在其左右，以明其不敢以上下神祇为无也。 所以尽事人之道，以事天地神祇也。 故阐事之先，必请命於上天之主宰，与夫三界分治之真灵。 曰府，曰司，曰宫，曰院。 凡有关世人死生罪福之所，必一一誊诚以闻。 或奏或申，或关或牒，又当随其尊卑等第为之。 或者谓天者积气之苍苍耳，安得有所谓宫庭官府，列职分司，如人世之多。 应之曰：子徒知积气苍苍中之，不有宫庭官府，之如人间世者而乐言之。 试观日月星辰之分布，昼夜寒暑之推迁，非各有主宰之神乎。 经曰：三华离便，大有妙庭，金阙玉房，森罗净泓者皆是也。 三华者，日月星也。 离便者，离便宫殿之谓也。 森罗者，森布罗列也。 浄泓者，言金阙玉房之清虚洞彻也。 且古先圣王，有为泰坛以祭天者，有所谓敢昭告于皇皇后帝者。 果谓积气苍苍，所无知乎。 况礼之月令，必曰其帝某其神某，是非各有主宰者乎。 经中之有宫府司院之者名，由汉武帝元封中，受经於西王母。

Sixth: *Transformation of the Millet Pearl*. Within our bodies naturally resides the Primordial Azure Heaven and Floating Black Earth, and the Millet Pearl—a single grain requiring no external pursuit. One must understand this principle: when dispersed, it fills the Six Directions; when gathered, it does not exceed a handful.

Seventh: *Central Harmonization of the Five Qi, Merging the Hundred Spirits*. Scholars must constantly uphold their resolve to cultivate their *qi*, guiding it to return to the Primal Sea and obey the commands of their original spirit. Thus, in all undertakings, the Hundred Spirits merge as one.

Eighth: *The Eight Latitudes*

1. *Flowing Essence and Jade Radiance*: This is the celestial essence, the upright and unyielding *qi* of Heaven, the numinous treasure of the cosmos. Scholars must seek it within themselves, nurturing it over time, until they behold the so-called five colors surging forth, illuminating the vast expanse. When applied, it repels all, dispels all, delivers all, and accomplishes all.

2. *Cavern Yang Talisman Fire*: According to the *Divine Book*, one harmonizes the *qi* movements of the sixty-four hexagrams with the true *qi* of the thirty-two heavens. Practiced over time, it unites one with the Dao in truth.

3. *Great Brahmanic Qi*: All true immortals transcend through this. The scripture states: "The Great Brahmanic *Qi* circulates through the Ten Directions." If scholars can ensure the Brahmanic *qi* within their bodies flows ceaselessly, even for a single breath, their merit in delivering others will be immeasurable. Ascending in the flesh to transcendence is but a secondary matter.

4. *Recitation in the Three Palaces*: The Three Palaces are the Three Fields. First, one must uphold precepts, restrain emotions, rectify the mind, and sincerely stabilize the true *qi* within. Only then, upon reciting scriptures, will the Infant ascend and descend, the Three Fields resonating with the recitation, and the merit and power align with the scriptural teachings.

5. *Repaying the Origin and Returning to the Beginning*: Scholars must, on the Three Primes, Eight Festivals, Five La Days, and the memorial days of departed ancestors, recite scriptures in accordance with the teachings to fulfill the Way of repaying the origin and returning to the beginning. For spring and autumn sacrifices, one should act according to the family’s means, striving to practice the Way of repaying origins without shame.

6. *Nine Grades of Hidden Merit*: The scripture states: When constellations fall into disarray and the sun and moon lose their harmony, one must perform purification rites, offer incense, and recite scriptures. When the four seasons fall out of order and yin and yang are imbalanced, one must perform purification rites, offer incense, and recite scriptures. When the sovereign faces calamity and wars erupt on all sides, one must perform purification rites, offer incense, and recite scriptures. When plagues spread and the multitudes perish, one must perform purification rites, offer incense, and recite scriptures. When teachers or friends pass away, one must perform purification rites, offer incense, and recite scriptures. Scholars must diligently practice these to accumulate hidden merit. As merit and virtue accumulate, the names are recorded in the heavens, spirits and gods submit in reverence, and in delivering the living and transcending the dead, every thought aligns with response. Attaining immortality in the flesh is no different from this.

7. *Mysterious Numinous Deliverance*: Scholars [missing character] must, on clear nights, pay homage to the Northern Dipper, swallow the Primordial August *Qi* according to the method, and seek the so-called Supreme Mystery’s Oneness. Guarding their true form, their bodies will radiate light, demons will not dare to intrude, and in moving the spirit to meet the Dao, every thought will resonate with the divine.

8. *Unceasing Deliverance*: The scripture states: "Constantly practice a kind heart." It also says: "Equalize with compassion and love." Upon seeing the widowed, orphaned, solitary, sick, hungry, or cold, one must think of aiding them. If one lacks the means, then broadly encourage others to do so. In years of famine, when corpses fill the ditches; in times of war, when the dead lie exposed; when the unburied are left unwept and wandering souls have no refuge—one must, according to scriptural methods and within one’s capacity, provide salvation. Thus, merit will extend to distant ancestors, and blessings will reach the living. The Supreme Pole Immortal Elder, Perfected Master Sa, Perfected Official Lu, and past patriarchs all devoted themselves to this, not betraying the scriptural teachings.

*Memorials, Petitions, and Documents in Ritual Purification*
The establishment of purification rites requires memorials, petitions, and documents, just as in the secular bureaucracy of the human world. This is the Way of serving humans applied to serving Heaven and Earth and the gods. It is a means of expressing sincerity—borrowing what we possess to resonate with the quiescent and unmoving void. Only then does one perceive its vastness, as if it were above, as if it were to the left and right, making clear that one does not dare regard the gods above and below as nonexistent. Thus, the Way of serving humans is fully applied to serving Heaven, Earth, and the gods. Therefore, before conducting affairs, one must first petition the sovereign of Heaven and the true spirits governing the Three Realms—whether called bureaus, offices, palaces, or courts. For all matters concerning the life, death, sins, and blessings of the world’s people, one must sincerely report each in detail. Whether submitting a memorial, petition, notice, or document, one must act according to the hierarchy of rank.

Some may argue that Heaven is merely the vast expanse of accumulated *qi*—how could there be palaces, courts, officials, and bureaus as in the human world? To this, one responds: You only recognize the accumulated *qi*’s vastness but delight in speaking of palaces, courts, officials, and bureaus as they exist in the human world. Observe the arrangement of the sun, moon, and stars, the alternation of day and night, and the succession of cold and heat—are these not each governed by their own deities? The scripture states: "The Three Luminaries depart, revealing wondrous courts, golden towers and jade chambers, all in serene clarity." The Three Luminaries are the sun, moon, and stars. "Depart" refers to the palaces and halls. "Serene clarity" describes the pristine emptiness and transparency of the golden towers and jade chambers. Moreover, the ancient sage-kings built the Grand Altar to sacrifice to Heaven, declaring, "Dare I solemnly report to the August Emperor." Could one truly claim that the vast expanse of accumulated *qi* is without awareness? Furthermore, the *Monthly Ordinances* always specify, "Its emperor is so-and-so, its god is so-and-so"—are these not each governed by their own deities? The names of palaces, bureaus, offices, and courts in the scriptures originate from when Emperor Wu of Han received the scriptures from the Queen Mother of the West during the Yuanfeng era.
